The majority judgment states that there are different but warranted justifications for ongoing protection afforded to child victims, witnesses and accused. The court acknowledged the open justice principle and the importance of freedom of expression, however held that the default position of offering the child participants ongoing protection did not result in a severe disadvantage on media freedom. Court declared section 154(3) invalid and ordered an interim reading-in which requires that a person who is subject to the protection of the section does not forfeit the protections upon reaching adulthood, and is entitled to consent to the publication of their identity after reaching adulthood, or if consent is refused, a competent court may be approach by the media to request an upliftment of the publication ban.

Cameron J, Froneman J and Jafta J agreed with the majority decision on the issue of victim protection but differed on the issue relating to ongoing protection. The court held that the right to freedom of expression and the principle of open justice tipped the scales in favour of a default regime in which anonymity protection ended when a child participant reaches 18 years, unless a court expressly extends the protection. The dissenting Justices held further that the conclusion that the rights to dignity, privacy and the best interests of the child were infringed was hard to understand in the context of the ongoing protection. This was because the issue was that section 154(3) failed to protect children when they turn 18 years of age hence the fear that the media were going to publish the first applicant’s identity when she turned 18. Otherwise before that she had been adequately protected by the section.

cases.title: Union of Refugee Women and Others v Director, Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Kondile AJ
cases.summary:
The applicants made an application regarding the rights of refugees to work in the private security industry in South Africa. The Private Security Industry Regulation Act 56 of 2001 required security service providers to register with the Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority. Section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act listed citizenship or permanent residence as a requirement for registration. Despite the provisions of section 23(1)(a), section 23(6) granted the Authority the decision to register any applicant as a security service provider, on good cause shown and on grounds which are not in conflict with the purpose of the Security Act and the objects of the Authority. The applicants challenged section 23(1)(a) on the basis that it constituted a violation of the right to equality and discriminated against them on the basis that they are not citizens or permanent residents. All of the respondents opposed the application.

The Private Security Industry Regulation Act 56 of 2001 required security service providers to register with the Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority. Section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act listed citizenship or permanent residence as a requirement for registration. The applicants argued that section 23(1)(a) was unconstitutional on the basis that it constituted a violation of the right to equality and discriminated against them on the basis that they are not citizens or permanent residents. The issue before the court was whether the provision of the Security Act to the extent it excluded refugees from its scope was unconstitutional.

The court held that while refugees were fully entitled to work in South Africa, section 22 of the Constitution limited the right to choose a job to citizens only. The right to equality was held not to be violated by section 23 of the Security Act. The court held that the private security industry was a special environment and at stake was the safety and security of the public at large. Section 12 of the Constitution provides everyone the right to freedom and security of the person, which included the right to be free from all forms of violence from either public or private sources. In a society damaged by violent crime, the importance of protecting this right could not be exaggerated.

The court held that the regulatory scheme was carefully designed for the purpose of screening entrants to the private security industry rather than constituting a blanket ban on the registration of refugees as private security service providers. Section 12 of the Constitution provides everyone the right to freedom and security of the person, which included the right to be free from all forms of violence from either public or private sources. That is not to say that foreign nationals, including refugees, are inherently less trustworthy than South Africans. In a country where xenophobia has caused increased suffering, it is important to stress this and that it was not that the Authority did not trust refugees. The Security Act was designed to limit eligibility for registration to people whose trustworthiness could be objectively verified. The preamble to the Act acknowledges that the right to security of the person is fundamental to the well-being and to the social and economic development of every person.

In their dissenting judgement, Mokgoro J and O'Regan J held that section 23(1)(a) of the Private Security Industry Regulation Act discriminated unfairly on the basis of refugee status. The court was not convinced that the purpose identified by the Minister to ensure that security service employees were trustworthy was really provided by the section. The dissenting judgment held that the order it would have proposed was to require that refugees who could meet the other requirements of the Act should not be barred from registration as security service providers. Those refugees who cannot meet those requirements should seek to establish that “good cause” exists for them to be registered as contemplated by section 23(6).

cases.title: NM and Others v Smith and Others [2007] ZACC 6; 2007 (5) SA 250 (CC); 2007 (7) BCLR 751 (CC)
cases.justicesConcurring: Madala J, Moseneke DCJ, Mokgoro J, Skweyiya J, Van der Westhuizen J, Yacoob J, Sachs J, Langa J and O’Regan J.
cases.summary:
The applicants who were HIV positive were involved in clinical trials. During these clinical trials, they raised concerns about the illnesses and fatalities amongst the patients. One of the concerns raised was that the consent forms for their trials were not explained to them. The second respondent was appointed to investigate the applicants' allegations. The second respondent then appointed a third party to conduct the investigation. The third-party issued a report that contained the names of the applicant but this report was sent to a few people. The first respondent was approached by the third respondent who wanted to write a biography about the second respondent. The published biography revealed the names and HIV status of the applicants.

The applicants who were HIV positive were involved in clinical trials. During these clinical trials, they raised concerns about the illnesses and fatalities amongst the patients. One of the concerns raised was that the consent forms for their trials were not explained to them. The second respondent was appointed to investigate the applicants' allegations. The second respondent then appointed a third party to conduct the investigation. The third-party issued a report that contained the names of the applicant but this report was sent to a few people. The first respondent was approached by the third respondent who wanted to write a biography about the second respondent. The published biography revealed the names and HIV status of the applicants.

The applicants asked the respondents to remove their names from the book, but the respondents refused to do so.

The issue was whetther the respondent had violated the applicants' right to privacy under section 14 of the Constitution when they published the HIV statuses of the applicants in the biography. The second issue was the balancing act between the right to privacy and freedom of speech.

The court when giving out its judgement mentioned that the respondents knew that the applicants had not given consent to have their HIV status published but they had gone ahead and published their names. This violated the applicants' rights to privacy and dignity.

The respondents could have used pseudonyms to protect the identity of the applicants. The applicants were found to have infringed on the applicants' rights to privacy and dignity and ordered to pay damages to the applicants.

The right to privacy is one that cannot be interfered with unless there is a social need that allows a person’s right to privacy to be violated.

There was no public interest that justified the violation of the applicant’s right to privacy in this case. The respondents did not establish if consent had been given by the applicants despite them having time to do so.

The respondents could have used pseudonyms which would not have taken away fro the authenticity of the book. The need for access to medical information was not sufficient to breach the applicants' right to privacy. There needs to be a very good reason for the public to want to be informed.

Madala J (Moseneke DCJ, Mokgoro J, Skweyiya J, Van der Westhuizen J and Yacoob J concurring) decided that the respondents were aware that the applicants had not given their consent but still went ahead and published their names, violating their rights to privacy and dignity.

Sachs J concurring decided that even though the respondents believed that the applicants had placed their medical status in the public domain, the sensitive nature of the information meant that the respondents had to take more care in verifying this belief.

Langa CJ concurred with the two judgments above but disagreed that the respondents had a further duty to verify the information and ensure that the applicants had consented.

O’Regan J disagreed with the above judgments. He agreed that there was limited consent but found that imposing an additional duty on the respondents to ensure that the applicants had consented to the original publication of their names would impose on the respondents' right to freedom of expression.

cases.title: Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development and Others v Prince (Clarke and Others Intervening); National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others v Rubin; National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others v Acton
cases.justicesConcurring: Zondo ACJ, Cameron J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Kathree Setiloane AJ, Kollapen AJ, Madlanga J, Mhlantla J, Theron J, and Zondi AJ.
cases.summary:
Three different High Court cases were heard as one case because they were all dealing with the same matter. The three cases argued that certain sections of the Drugs and Drug Trafficking Act (Drugs Act) and the Medicines and Related Substances Control Act were unconstitutional.

The High Court declared certain sections of the above Acts to be unconstitutional and the State appealed this decision to the present court.

Three different High Court cases were heard as one case because they were all dealing with the same matter. The three cases argued that certain sections of the Drugs and Drug Trafficking Act (Drugs Act) and the Medicines and Related Substances Control Act (Medicines Act) were unconstitutional.

The issues before the court were whether:

1. Section 4(b) of the Drugs Act which prohibited the use or possession of any dangerous dependence producing substances; 2. Section 5(b) of the Drugs Act which prohibited dealing in dangerous dependence producing substances; 3. Section 22A(9)(a)(i) read with Schedule 7 of the Medicines Act that prohibited acquiring, using, possessing, manufacturing, or supplying cannabis; 4. Section 22A(10) of the Medicines Act which prohibited the sale or administration of cannabis except for medical purposes were unconstitutional.

The court decided that s 4(b) and 5(b) of the Drugs Act together with Part III of Schedule 2 of the Drugs Act and ss 22A(9)(a)(i) and 22A(10) of the Medicines Act together with Schedule 7 of the Medicines Act were unconstitutional because they violated section 14 of the Constitution.

The sections were found to violate the right of privacy to extent that they prohibited the use, possession, and cultivation of cannabis in a private dwelling personal consumption.

The appeal by the state was dismissed.

The right to privacy entitles an adult to cultivate or possess cannabis in private for their personal consumption and the above sections infringed on this right. That the above sections were an unjustifiable limitation on the right to privacy. The right to privacy was not limited to a home or dwelling because there are other places other than a person’s home or dwelling where prohibiting the use or possession of cannabis would infringe on the person’s right to privacy.

cases.title: Freedom of Religion South Africa v Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ, Basson AJ, Cameron J, Dlodlo AJ, Froneman J, Goliath AJ, Khampepe J, Mhlantla J, Petse AJ, and Theron J
cases.summary:
A father was accused of abusing his son and he was convicted of common assault despite him raising the defence of reasonable and moderate chastisement of a child. He then appealed this decision to the High Court. The High Court dismissed the father’s claim and ruled that the defence of moderate and reasonable chastisement of a child was unconstitutional based on age, equal protection of the law, dignity, freedom from all forms of violence and degradation, and bodily and psychological integrity.

The applicant then applied to the Constitutional Court to challenge the decision of the High Court because it said that the decision limited its right to religious freedom as provided by section 15 of the Constitution.

The issue before the court was whether the High Court’s ruling that the defence of reasonable chastisement was unconstitutional was correct.

The court agreed with the stance taken by the High Court and decided that children could be disciplined without having to use moderate and reasonable chastisement. There were less restrictive means available to discipline children. The court held that moderate and reasonable chastisement was indeed unconstitutional as it violated sections 10, 12(1)(c) and 28(2) of the Constitution.

Unlike the constitutional protection available to children, the right to freedom of religion does not entitle a parent to moderately and reasonably chastise a child. The Constitution does not acknowledge a cultural right that entitles a parent to moderately and reasonably chastise their child.

The court held that there are less restrive means to enforce discipline in children. The limitation of the rights to practice their religion in moderate and reasonable chastisement was justifiable in light of the rights of the child that it violated.

cases.title: Christian Education South Africa v Minister of Education
cases.justicesConcurring: Sachs J
cases.summary:
The applicant brought an appeal before the Constitutional Court arguing that the South African Schools Act which prohibited corporal punishments in school violated the rights of parents and learners to freedom of religion.

The applicant further argued that the South African Schools act interfered with the right to participate in the cultural life of their choice, the right to enjoy their culture and practise their religion.

The applicant in their argument stated that parents delegated the authority to discipline their children to the teachers and that this delegation was in accordance with their beliefs. The applicant argued that corporal punishment in schools was done biblically and that prohibiting corporate punishment was unconstitutional because it violated section 15.

The question before the court was whether the South African Schools Act violated the rights of parents of children in independent schools who, in line with their religious convictions had consented to corporeal punishment.

The court did find that the South African Schools Act in particular section 10 which prohibited corporate punishment was a reasonable and justifiable limitation of the parents' rights under section 15. This was because the state had to take steps to reduce violence in public and private life. The state also had a duty to protect children.

The court added that it would be difficult to monitor the administration of corporal punishment in schools and there was a possibility that teachers might act excessively.

Religious practises are based on faith and this is in contrast to public or private concerns which are evaluated according to their reasonableness.Believers cannot claim an automatic right to be exempted by their beliefs from the laws of the country. The state on the other hand cannot put believers in positions where they have to choose between their faith and obeying the rule of law.

While parents may no longer authorise teachers to corporally punish their children, parents are not deprived of bringing up their children according to their Christian beliefs. The effect of the South African Schools Act was to disempower schools from delivering corporal punishment.

(1) The Constitution distinguishes between personal and community religious rights, at sections 15 and 31(1) respectively. These rights have both individual and community dimensions and are often exercised communally. Section 31 protects communal enjoyment and exercising of religious, cultural and language rights and is supported by the right to freedom of association (section 18).

(2) If the community ‘dies’ (ceases to exist), an individual can no longer exercise their community rights under section 31(1) in respect of that (dead) community.

(3) Section 31(1) protects communities not by giving community groups ‘legal personality’ (rights in-and-of themselves), but by protecting the ability of individuals (in the communities) to exercise their rights collectively, specifically by enabling individuals to join other individuals of their community and by preventing the state from denying or interfering with individual rights collectively under section 31(1).

(4) Section 31(1) protects communities qualitatively: the degree of protection afforded to a community is not dependent on how large or small the community is. (The Court recognised that larger communities are likely to have more power and say in legislative processes than smaller ones, and so smaller communities are more likely to need more protection under section 31 to protect them from majority rule.)

(5) Section 31(2) prohibits the rights in section 31(1) from being exercised inconsistently with any rights in the Bill of Rights. Section 31(2) is therefore an internal limit on the rights under section 31(1) – preventing community practices which violate constitutional rights from being shielded from legislative or judicial intervention, and preventing oppression of individuals within communities by those communities.

cases.title: South African Broadcasting Corporation Limited v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Langa CJ, Kondile AJ, Madala J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Van Heerden AJ,  Yacoob J, Sachs J  Moseneke DCJ and Mokgoro J
cases.summary:
The applicant was appealing a judgement made by the Supreme Court of Appeal where it was only granted permission to broadcast visuals of the respondents pending trial but without sound. The reasoning behind this decision was that the respondents' right to a fair trial was sufficient enough to justify the limitation of the applicant’s right to freedom of expression.

The issue before the Constitutional Court was whether the test applied by the Supreme Court of Appeal where broadcasting would not be permitted unless the Court was satisfied that justice for the respondents would not be affected limited section 16.

The court agreed with the Supreme Court of Appeal and found that allowing the applicant to only broadcast visuals without sound was a limitation of the applicant’s right to freedom of expression. However, it was justifiable taking into context the importance of the respondents' right to a fair trial.

The refusal to allow the applicant to have sound recordings of the respondents' hearing affected the applicants' right to freedom of expression under section 16 of the Constitution. The public also has a fundamental constitutional right to freedom of expression and this encompasses the right to receive information and ideas.

The public should as far as possible be informed of what goes on in the courts. The right to freedom of expression encompasses the right of the media to not only gather footage and deliver it to the public but to also broadcast that footage.

However, in this particular case, the respondents' right to a fair trial as well as the impact of the broadcasting on witnesses was sufficient to justify the limitation of the right to freedom of expression.

The majority judgement written by Langa CJ (Kondile Aj, Madala J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Van Heerden AJ, and Yacoob J concurring) agreed with the approach taken by the Supreme Court of Appeal that the applicant only be granted visual rights without sound.

Sachs J concurred with the majority but for different reasons.

Moseneke DCJ (Mokgoro J concurring) dissented from the majority judgement. The test used by the Supreme Court in deciding not to allow the applicant to broadcast the sound of the proceedings put the right to a fair trial above that of freedom of speech. This was an inappropriate test because there must be no hierarchy of rights and this prejudiced the right to freedom of expression. Secondly, Moseneke DCJ found that by banning sound in the visuals to be aired by the applicant, the court had failed to consider if there were less restrictive means to protect the respondent’s right to a fair trial.

cases.title: Print Media South Africa and Another v Minister of Home Affairs and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Skweyiya J (Mogoeng CJ, Cameron J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Nkabinde J, Maya AJ and Zondo AJ concurring)
cases.summary:
The High Court declared certain provisions in the Films and Publications Act (Act) unconstitutional.

After the Act was amended, it required publishers except for newspapers to submit for prior approval to an administrative body, publications that showed amongst other things sexual conduct that violated or disrespected the right to human dignity, was degrading or was an incitement to cause harm.

Failure to submit this material to the administrative body before publication was a criminal offence.

The question before the court was whether the provisions were in line with the Constitution and if they limited section 16, whether it was a justifiable limitation.

The court found that the fact that there had to be administrative classification before publication limited a publisher's right to freedom of expression. This limitation was not justifiable because it did not achieve its intended purpose. The court also found that there were less restrictive means to achieve the purpose.

The provision was found to be unconstitutional.

The Act regulates freedom of expression in varying degrees. Freedom of speech unlike other rights does not require regulation to give it effect, relegating the right amounts to limiting it. The prior classification requirement set out by the Act limited the right.

Administrative prior classification before publication was a transfer of control from the publisher wanting to exercise the right to freedom of speech to the administrative body.

The administrative body was now the decision-maker in respect of the right to freedom of speech of the publisher because the administrative body got to determine if expression should be made public and not the publisher. The provisions were declared unconstitutional.

In the majority judgement written by Skweyiya J ( Mogoeng CJ, Cameron J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Nkabinde J, Maya AJ, and Zondo AJ concurring), the court found that the requirement that publishers submit their work before publication was a limitation of the right to freedom of expression.

Van der Westhuizen J (Yacoob ADCJ and Froneman J concurring) agreed with the above judgement except for adding that the provision was constitutionally invalid because it embodied a system of prior restraint that was based on vague criteria.

cases.title: Chirwa v Transnet Limited and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Skweyiya J , Moseneke DCJ, Madala J, Navsa AJ, Nkabinde J, Sachs J, Van  Der Westhuizen J, Ngcobo J, Langa CJ, Mokgoro J and O’Regan J
cases.summary:
The applicant, a public sector employee was dismissed from a state-owned company. After her dismissal, she referred the matter to the CCMA as an unfair dismissal. The CCMA failed to resolve the matter within the stipulated time of 30 days and recommended arbitration in terms of the Labour Relations Act.

The applicant did not follow this recommendation and instead approached the High Court to set aside the disciplinary hearing that resulted in her dismissal and reinstate her. The applicant argued that the reason for her approaching the High Court for relief was because she had two causes of action available to her. One flowing from the Labour Relations Act (LRA) and the other flowing from the Bill of Rights read together with the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act (PAJA).

The question posed before the court was whether the High Court and the Labour Court both had jurisdiction regarding employment disputes.

Section 23 of the LRA provides that everyone has the right to fair labour practices. This was the section that the court relied on when issuing its judgement.

Firstly the court found that the applicant was not afforded a choice of which court to bring her action. She was not be put in a preferential position because she was a public sector employee and could rely on PAJA.

Secondly, the LRA gave remedies that the applicant should have relied on. The applicant should have relied on those remedies first and if she was not satisfied, then she could have approached the High Court. The applicant's matter was dismissed.

Section 23 which the LRA was enacted to give effect to serves as the main guarantee for all employees.

All employees including public service employees, except those excluded by the Act, are covered by unfair dismissal provisions and dispute resolution mechanisms.

The LRA does not differentiate between the state as an employer and any other employer. If the applicant wanted to rely on a constitutional issue, she must have first gone through the remedies provided for by the LRA before raising the issue in a different forum.

cases.title: National Union of Metal Workers of South Africa v Intervalve (Pty) Ltd and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Cameron J, Mogoeng CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Khampepe J, Leeuw AJ, Zondo J,  Nkabinde J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Madlanga J and Van Der Westhuizen J
cases.summary:
The applicant represented employees of the respondents who were dismissed after participating in a strike. The applicant sought to add new employers in its application in the Labour Court. The Labour Court allowed the addition but this addition was overturned in the Labour Appeal Court. The Labour Appeal Court found that the applicant had failed to refer the matter for conciliation first and as such the Labour Court had no jurisdiction to hear the matter.

The applicant represented employees of the respondents who were dismissed after participating in a strike. The applicant sought to add new employers in its application in the Labour Court. The Labour Court allowed the addition but this addition was overturned in the Labour Appeal Court. The Labour Appeal Court found that the applicant had failed to refer the matter for conciliation first and as such the Labour Court had no jurisdiction to hear the matter.Section 191 of the LRA provides that a dispute be referred for conciliation. The applicant had failed to refer the dispute for conciliation and also to join every party who was a respondent.

The main question that the applicant brought was whether s 191 of the LRA could be interpreted given the object of section 23 of the Constitution which prevented unfair labour practices.

The court dismissed the applicants' case because the applicant was aware of the law and procedures that it needed to follow and could not rely on section 23 for its failure to do the right thing.

Section 23 of the Constitution allows for the existence of trade unios and also prevents unfair labour practices.

However, trade unions who aware of the procedures that need to be followed in lodging a complaint and fail to do so cannot use section 23.

The Labour Relations Act was enacted to give effect to section 23 and therefore section 23 cannot be used directly unless the Labour Relations Act is being challenged regarding its constitutionality.

The majority judgement by Cameron J (Mogoeng CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Khampepe J, Leeuw AJ and Zondo J concurring) agreed with the Labour Appeal Court.

Nkabinde J ( Froneman J, Jafta J, Madlanga J and Van Der Westhuizen J concurring) found that there had been some compliance with the Labour Relations Act (LRA) when interpreted to give effect to fair labour practices and access to the courts. Strict compliance in some instances interferes with the purpose of the LRA.

cases.title: Dikoko v Mokhatla
cases.justicesConcurring: Mokgoro J, Langa CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Madala J, Ngcobo J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Sachs J, Skweyiya J, Van der Westhuizen J and Yacoob J
cases.summary:
The council had a policy under which R300 was payable towards the payment of the cell-phone account of each councillor. Any amount above that must either be justified or be paid by the Councillor and be deducted from their salary. The Council submitted its financial annual report which revealed that the applicant had an outstanding amount in excess of R3,200. When the applicant appeared before the Standing Committee to provide an explanation, he made a statement to the effect that his overdue indebtedness was because the respondent had changed the accounting procedures deliberately to attack his integrity.

The respondent then instituted an action for damages against the applicant in the High Court, arguing that the applicant’s statement was defamatory. The applicant argued that the statement enjoyed privilege under the relevant legislation.

The court unanimously held that the relevant constitutional and legislative provisions relied on by the applicant only conferred privilege onto provincial legislatures. Further, the applicant’s explanation of his personal indebtedness to the Council did not constitute the Council’s real and legitimate business. Therefore, privilege was not conferred onto the applicant on that basis either. Therefore, he could be sued for defamation.

Regarding how much in damages, Moseneke DCJ writing for the majority held that the general rule is that damages should be left to the determination of the trial court and that an appellate court should only interfere when there are special circumstances which justify interfering with the lower court’s award. In this case, there were no special circumstances that justified interfering with the High Court’s award.

Sachs J, in a separate judgment, proposes that the law of defamation should be developed so as to move away from an almost exclusive preoccupation with monetary awards, which are unsuitable to restoring the damage done to a person’s reputation and which often serve to drive parties further apart rather than to reconcile them.

Moseneke DCJ held that although sentimental damages for defamation is a common law remedy, it can nonetheless fall under ”appropriate relief” within the meaning of section 38 of the Constitution. Moseneke DCJ relied on Fose v Minister of Safety and Security, where the court held that there is no reason in principle why ’appropriate relief’ should not include an award of damages, where such an award is necessary to protect and enforce rights in the Bill of Rights. However, Moseneke DCJ then made clear that he was not conclusively deciding this question.

Mokgoro J dissented on the issue of quantum. For Mokgoro J, an appeal court can replace the trial court’s award if it finds that, in the exercise of its discretion, the trial court had been influenced by wrong principles of law or a mistaken view of the facts. In this case, the trial court had not taken all the relevant factors into account.

cases.title: Glenister v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Langa CJ
cases.summary:
The applicant applied for leave to appeal against a decision of the High Court and an application for direct access to the Constitutional Court in terms of Rule 18 read with section 167(6) regarding the constitutional invalidity of various provisions of the National Prosecuting Authority Amendment Act 56 of 2008 and the South African Police Service Amendment Act 57 of 2008, which created the Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation (DPCI) and disbanded the Directorate of Special Operations. The challenged laws were passed by Parliament, and on 27 January 2009 they were assented to and signed by the President. On 17 April 2009, the applicant challenged the constitutional validity of the impugned laws based on the absence of a rational basis for the enactment of the laws in question. The applicant also alleged that the process of enactment failed to comply with various constitutional obligations relating to accountability and upholding international obligations and allowing the NPA to properly exercise its functions.

The applicant made an application to determine the constitutional validity of the National Prosecuting Authority Amendment Act (NPAA Act) and the South African Police Service Amendment Act (SAPSA Act). The issue before the court was whether the national legislation that created the Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation, known as the Hawks (DPCI), and disbanded the Directorate of Special Operations, known as the Scorpions (DSO), is constitutionally valid. The court it held that the Constitution imposed an obligation on the state to establish and maintain an independent body to combat corruption and organised crime. While the Constitution did not expressly command that a corruption-fighting unit should be established, its scheme taken as a whole imposed duty on the state to set up an effective and independent mechanism to prevent and root out corruption.

The provisions of section 37(4)(b)(i) of the Constitution, provided that legislation that derogated from the Bill of Rights had to be consistent with the state’s obligations under international law applicable to states of emergency, possibly transforms the rights and obligations embodied in international agreements into constitutional rights and obligations, but only in the limited context of states of emergency.

The court found that the DPCI did not meet the constitutional requirement of appropriate independence. The reason behind the court’s conclusion was that the DPCI was insufficiently protected from political influence in its structure and functioning. This was because the DPCI’s activities had to be coordinated by Cabinet. The Court held that the legislation in question was constitutionally invalid to the extent that it failed to secure an adequate degree of independence for the DPCI.

The court held that the Constitution imposed an obligation on the state to establish and maintain an independent body to combat corruption and organised crime. Section 37(4)(b)(i) entailed that legislation that deviates from the Bill of Rights had to be consistent with the state’s obligations under international law applicable to states of emergency. It found that the Constitution's system, taken as a whole, and the international law agreements which are binding on the state imposed a pressing duty on the state to set up an effective and independent mechanism to prevent and root out corruption. The Court upheld the appeal and declared that the offending legislative provisions establishing the DPCI constitutionally invalid to the extent that they did not secure adequate independence, and suspended the declaration of constitutional invalidity for a period of eighteen months to give Parliament the opportunity to remedy the defect.

The court held that section 34 of the Constitution entrenches the right to have disputes resolved ”in a fair public hearing before a court”. This demonstrates that open justice is an important part of the right to a fair trial. The principle of open justice is ordinarily observed by allowing the public to be able to attend all hearings, as well as the press.

For the court, the key question was whether this right extends to the live broadcast of proceedings on radio and televesion. The court held that ordinarly it will not be in the interests of justice for trial proceedings to be subjected to trial proceedings. In respect of appeal proceedings, courts will have to exercise their discretion in terms of section 173 of the Constitution. In so doing, they should take care to ensure rights such as those in s34 are not limited unjustifiability.

Moseneke DCJ would have upheld the appeal. For Moseneke DCJ, the media’s right to free expression under section 16 of the Constitution must include the right to gather information, video footage and audio recordings for dissemination to the public. Thus, the Supreme Court of Appeal misappreciated the nature of the enquiry it was called upon to make. Further, for Moseneke DCJ, the SCA erred on the facts by concluding that allowing the public broadcaster to record and broadcast the proceedings would “inhibit justice” because counsel and the court would be distracted by the extensive publicity surrounding the appeals such that an unfair hearing would result. Moseneke DCJ was not persuaded that senior counsel would not address the court with their “customary dignity, erudition and helpfulness”. Nor was he persuaded that judges would not discharge their obligations.

In their dissenting judgement, Deputy Chief Justice Moseneke and Justice Cameron held that section 7(2) of the Constitution, while giving rise to an obligation on the state to fight corruption and organised crime, it did not specifically impose an obligation on the state to establish an independent corruption-fighting unit. It further held that, insofar as such a constitutional obligation is found, the structural and operational autonomy of the DPCI was secured through institutional and legal mechanisms that were adequately designed to prevent undue interference and safeguarded the independence of the DPCI. The court concluded that the appeal must be dismissed.

Mokgoro J wrote a separate judgment in which she concurred with the dissenting judgment of Moseneke DCJ.

cases.title: South African Broadcasting Corporation Limited v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Langa CJ, Kondile AJ, Madala J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Van Heerden AJ and Yacoob J, Sachs J, Moseneke DCJ and Mokgoro J
cases.summary:
Mr Shaik was convicted by the Durban High Court on several counts relating to corruption. The court found that he had bribed Mr Zuma to protect a French armaments company from exposure by official investigation. Mr Shaik sought leave to appeal to the Supreme Court of Appeal.

The South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) sought permission from the court to televise the proceedings and broadcast live on radio. The Supreme Court of Appeal denied the application on the basis that broadcasting would violate the Mr Shaik’s fair trial rights, and might prejudice the trial of Mr Zuma which would occur at a later date. SABC then sought leave to appeal from the Constitutional Court.

The majority held that leave to appeal should be dismissed. The court held that in dismissing the appeal the Supreme Court of Appeal properly exercised its discretion in terms of section 173 of the Constitution. This provision gives a court the inherent power to regulate its own process. Such discretion must however be exercised in accordance with the interests of justice. The SCA considered all the arguments of both parties and having weighed up all the factors, decided that given the specific nature of this case it was not in the interests of justice for the application to be granted.

The majority held that a court, in determining whether to permit sound broadcasting of court proceedings, must adequately consider and weigh in the balance the relevant constitutional principles, particularly the rights in the Bill of Rights. The majority further held that the SCA had done so in the present case. In the circumstances, the majority held that the reasoning and conclusion of the SCA could not be faulted.

Sachs J filed a separate judgment concurring with the order made by the majority but for different reasons. These reasons related particularly to those parts of the majority judgment dealing with the manner in which the exercise of the Supreme Court of Appeal’s discretion should be conceptualized and also on the limited ground that the SABC erred in not raising the question of electronic broadcast timeously to ensure that proper safeguards were put in place.

The court held that section 34 of the Constitution entrenches the right to have disputes resolved ”in a fair public hearing before a court”. This demonstrates that open justice is an important part of the right to a fair trial. The principle of open justice is ordinarily observed by allowing the public to be able to attend all hearings, as well as the press.

For the court, the key question was whether this right extends to the live broadcast of proceedings on radio and televesion. The court held that ordinarly it will not be in the interests of justice for trial proceedings to be subjected to trial proceedings. In respect of appeal proceedings, courts will have to exercise their discretion in terms of section 173 of the Constitution. In so doing, they should take care to ensure rights such as those in section 34 are not limited unjustifiability.

Moseneke DCJ would hae upheld the appeal. For Mosenek DCJ, the media’s right to free expression under section 16 of the Constitution must include the right to gather information, video footage and audio recordings for dissemination to the public. Thus, the Supreme Court of Appeal misappreciated the nature of the enquiry it was called upon to make. Further, for Moseneke DCJ, the SCA erred on the facts by concluding that allowing the public broadcaster to record and broadcast the proceedings would “inhibit justice” because counsel and the court would be distracted by the extensive publicity surrounding the appeals such that an unfair hearing would result. Moseneke DCJ was not persuaded that senior counsel would not address the court with their “customary dignity, erudition and helpfulness”. Nor was he persuaded that judges would not discharge their obligations.

Mokgoro J wrote a separate judgment in which she concurred with the dissenting judgment of Moseneke DCJ.

cases.title: University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others v Minister of Justice and Correctional Services and Others; Association of Debt Recovery Agents NPC v University of Stellenbosch Legal   Aid Clinic and Others; Mavava Trading 279 (Pty) Ltd and Others v University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Bosielo AJ, Cameron J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Madlanga J, Mhlantla J, Nkabinde J and Zondo J
cases.summary:
The Stellenbosch Law Clinic’s clients all had emoluments attachment orders issued against them by clerks of the court employed in various Magistrates’ offices. They had approached a company known as SA Multiloan in Stellenbosch for small loans. Later when they fell into arrears, the creditor provider demanded that they sign further documents which resulted in default judgments and emoluments attachment orders obtained by the credit providers. This allowed for the deduction of the judgment debt from their salaries or wages.

As a result of this, all the applicants approached the Law Clinic to institute proceedings in the High Court to have section 65(J) declared unconstitutional. Their argument was that section 65(J) allowed for emoluments attachment orders to be obtained without judicial oversight. The High Court agreed with them and declared the section unconstitutional and therefore invalid. Application was then filed to the Constitutional Court to confirm invalidity of section 65(J).

The majority judgment, written by Cameron J, disagreed with Jafta J’s conclusion that it was possible to interpret section 65J as providing for judicial oversight. Section 65J(2) licenses the issuing of an emoluments attachment order where the debtor consents in writing; or if “the court has so authorised”. The conjunction “or” seems to make plain that an emoluments attachment order may be obtained through the debtor’s written consent even when the court has not authorised it. Additionally, section 65J(1) posits that a judgment creditor, not a court, causes an emoluments attachment order to be issued from a court. And once issued, section 65J(5) provides that the order may be executed “as if it were a court judgment”. This wording allows for execution without judicial oversight. The majority judgment therefore concluded that the plain language of the provision shows it permitted judicially unsanctioned enforcement of judgment debts. Therefore, the section was unconstitutional.

Zondo J concurred with the majority judgment but wrote separately. He took the view that in order for section 65J(1)(a) to be read to mean that it is the court that issues emoluments attachment orders, one would have to read the phrase “issued from the court” to mean “issued by the court”. Zondo J held that there is no room for this interpretation.

The remedy adopted by Zondo J was supported by the majority. It was one of a combination of reading-in and severance and not the remedy adopted by the High Court. Accordingly, Zondo J did not confirm the order of constitutional invalidity made by the High Court, but rather ordered the reading-in, and severance of, certain words in section 65J(2)(a) and (b) in order to remedy the constitutional defect.

The majority held that a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any form of property occurs without judicial oversight of a court.

Jafta J held that the High Court erred in proceeding from the premise that s65J(2) did not provide for judicial oversight without interpreting that section. He held that the Court was bound to determine for itself whether indeed the section failed to provide for judicial oversight.

Jafta J held further that it should be determined whether the words “from the court” are capable of a meaning that accords with the assumed constitutional guarantee that, whenever execution is sought against one’s property – regardless of whether movable or immovable – the execution must be subject to judicial oversight.

Jafta J held that section 65J indeed provides for judicial supervision. Therefore, assuming that the Constitution requires judicial supervision when emoluments attachment orders are issued, the section meets the requirement. Jafta J added that in these circumstances he cannot confirm the order of invalidity made by the High Court.

cases.title: Fedsure Life Assurance Ltd and Others v Greater Johannesburg Transitional Metropolitan Council and Others
cases.justicesConcurring:
Chaskalson P, Goldstone J and O’Regan J (Ackermann J and Madala J)

Kriegler J (Langa DP, Mokgoro, Sachs J and Yacoob J)

*The Court was unanimous in approach and interpretation of  ‘administrative action’.
cases.summary:
[Note: This case was decided under the Interim Constitution, but the decision remains relevant and applicable.]

[The Eastern Metropolitan Substructure, Western Metropolitan Substructure, Southern Metropolitan Substructure and the Northern Metropolitan Substructure were all transitional substructures of the Greater Johannesburg Transitional Metropolitan Council as at June 1996.]

The metropolitan structures passed resolutions to substantially increase general rates on property and property rights within the Eastern and Northern Metropolitan Substructure areas, thereby generating surpluses in income from those areas to offset deficits in the budgets of the Western and Southern Metropolitan Substructures and Greater Johannesburg Transitional Metropolitan Council through subsidisation.

The result was that ratepayers in some areas were required to pay increased property rates and others enjoyed a decrease in their rates. Ratepayers from the Eastern Metropolitan Substructure challenged a resolutions.

Section 24 of the Interim Constitution enshrined the right to administrative justice and required that administrative action (decisions) be lawful, justifiable and procedurally fair. (Similar to the section 33 of the Constitution of the Republic of South Africa, 1996 which enshrines the right to just administrative action).

Ratepayers of the Eastern Metropolitan Substructure (of the Greater Johannesburg Transitional Metropolitan Council) the challenged budgetary decisions (resolutions) of the municipal councils to increase rates on property and property rights in some sub-areas and not others. The ratepayers argued, amongst other things, that the resolutions were unlawful ‘administrative action’ under section 24 of the Interim Constitution.

The Court ruled that whilst the government (in all spheres) was always required by the principle of legality – under the rule of law – to act lawfully at all times, the resolutions of the municipal councils did not constitute administrative action but were instead legislative action. This was because the municipal councils were ‘competent authorities’ exercising their own constitutional powers in taking the resolutions by way of collective decision-making. The Court upheld the challenged resolutions on all grounds, including that they were lawful legislative action.

The Court:

(1) Identified the ‘principle of legality’ as a part of the ‘rule of law’. (The rule of law a foundational constitutional value under section 1(c) of the Constitution.) The Court outlined that, as applicable to the case, the principle of legality requires that the legislative and executive branches in every sphere may only exercise powers if granted by the law; and that organs of state must act within the powers lawfully granted to them.

(2) Determined that action by a legislative body is not ordinarily (can almost never be) administrative action where the legislative body: (i) exercises original powers (i.e. powers granted by the Constitution); and (ii) takes the action in a deliberative manner (i.e. through collective decision-making).

(3) Recognised local government as co-equal with the provincial and national spheres of government in terms of local government’s constitutional competencies; and that local government authorities are empowered to regulate affairs within their jurisdictions and their constitutional and other powers. (Prior to the Interim and 1996 Constitutions, local government could only exercise delegated powers granted by Parliament.)

cases.title: Greys Marine Hout Bay (Pty) Ltd and Others v Minister of Public Works and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Nugent JA (Scott JA, Nvsa JA, Mthiyane JA, Maya AJA)
cases.summary:
Minister of Public Works decided to grant a lease of portion of the Hout Bay quayside to a company, Bluefin (Pty) Ltd, established by a group of women who were entering the fishing industry (from which they were historically excluded). Bluefin (Pty) Ltd intended to build and operate a fish-processing factory and restaurant on the property. Other tenants opposed the Minister’s decision, arguing that Bluefin (Pty) Ltd’s activites would increase traffic congestion, limit access to the waterfront, and deprive existing tenants and visitors of parking space.

Section 33 of the Constitution and the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 2000 (PAJA), respectively enshrine and give effect to the right to just administrative action. The right to just administrative action entitles persons to lawful, procedurally fair and reasonable decision-making (action) by public officials (and sometimes private persons) in certain contexts.

PAJA lays down many grounds to challenge such decisions. PAJA, and these grounds, only apply to decisions which constitute ‘administrative action’ as defined in PAJA. Therefore, in order to challenge a decision under PAJA, the decision must satisfy all of the definitional requirements for ‘administrative action’ as listed in section 1 of PAJA.

The questions in Greys Marine were whether the Minister’s decision to grant a lease to Bluefin was administrative action or not; and if so, whether the tenants’ and visitors’ right to just administrative action had been violated in the granting of the lease.

The Court found that the Minister’s decision was administrative action as defined in PAJA because: it was made in the exercise of a public power conferred by legislation (Disposal of State Land Act 48 of 1961); involved implementation of policy as opposed to policy-making; was made in the ordinary course of administering the property of the state; and was had immediate and direct legal effect for the rights of individuals concerned (namely, Bluefin).

However, the Court dismissed the appeal by the tenants, finding that the tenants had not proven any that they had rights or legitimate expectations (legally recognisable interests) which were infringed by the administrative action (the Minister decision to grant the lease).

The Court:

(1) Emphasized that what is, or is not, administrative action depends on the nature of the power being exercised as opposed to the status or position of the person exercising the power. The fact that a Minister is a high-ranking member of government does not mean that they do not, at times, perform administrative action: they might.

(2) Observed that ‘administrative action’ is a difficult concept to define, and that it will almost always involve policy to some degree or another; but that administrative action is more the implementation/execution/application of law and policy in carrying out the daily functions of the state, than policy-making or law-making itself.

(3) Interpreted ‘rights’ in PAJA’s definition of ‘administrative action’ broadly to include ‘legitimate expectations’, thereby expanding the scope (applicability) of PAJA to include infringements of legitimate expectations. (Legitimate, or reasonable, expectations are expectations arising from express promises or from regular practices which can reasonably be expected to continue.)

(4) Noted that ‘rights’ under PAJA’s definition might also include future rights (i.e. rights that have not yet vested or are not yet exercisable): provided that the action can impact on the future rights in that it has the capacity to affect them, the action might amount to administrative action and be challengeable under PAJA.

cases.title: Bato Star Fishing (Pty) Ltd v Minister of Environmental Affairs and Tourism and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: O’Regan J (Chaskalson CJ, Langa DCJ, Ackermann J, Goldstone J, Madala J, Mokgoro J Moseneke J, Ngcobo J, Sachs J and Yacoob J)
cases.summary:
In context of the deep-sea hake trawl fishing sector, the applicant, Bato Star Fishing (Pty) Ltd, applied for an allowance of 12 000 tonnes in catch for the 2002-2005 fishing seasons. It was only allocated a quota of 873 tonnes by the Respondent, the Chief Director (Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism). Aggrieved, Bato Star Fishing challenged the quota of 873 tonnes in court (on review).

Section 33 of the Constitution and the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 2000 (PAJA), respectively enshrine and give effect to the right to just administrative action. The right to just administrative action entitles persons to lawful, procedurally fair and reasonable decision-making (action) by public officials (and sometimes even private persons).

The question was whether the decision by the Chief Director of the Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism to grant Bato Star a 873 tonnes fishing quota for 2002-2005, as opposed to a greater tonnage allowance, was unreasonable or procedurally unfair (and therefore invalid) administrative action under PAJA and section 33.

The Court acknowledged that would improper to intervene in decision-making of other branches of government unless justified, given that the judiciary is not best placed or ordinarily empowered to take legislative or executive decisions. Ultimately, after analysing the relevant factors, O’Regan J determined that the Court could not intervene and invalidate the Chief Director’s decision because it was not unreasonable. Similarly, the Court found that the Chief Director had properly applied their mind to Bato Star’s application for a 12 000 tonnes fishing quota by individually rating all applications according to the relevant criteria. Finally, the Court found that the decision was procedurally fair because it was based on the applicable policy which was made available.

The Court repeated that PAJA (under section 33 of the Constitution) has largely replaced the common law as a source of administrative law, and that parties must therefore rely on PAJA first and foremost, and except in exceptional circumstances, when challenging administrative action.

O’Regan J outlined that what a ‘reasonable’ decision is dependant on the circumstances of each case, taking into account a range of factors including the nature of the decision, expertise of the decision-maker, the nature of the competing interests involved, policy considerations, the impact of the decision, whether the decision will reasonably result in the achievement of the goal, is reasonably supported by the facts or reasons for it and whether a balance between factors has been struck by the decision-maker.

It is essential that courts respect the roles and constitutional authority of other branches of government when reviewing decisions, especially where the decision involves special expertise or skill – courts should not ‘take-over’ from other branches. However, this does not mean that a court should ‘rubber-stamp’ and automatically approve of unreasonable decisions merely because the case is complex.

Ngcobo J (all other judges concurring) wrote separately to discuss the need for transformation and the achievement of equality generally and in the fishing sector.

cases.title: Amod v Multilateral Motor Vehicle Accidents Fund
cases.justicesConcurring: Chaskalson P, Langa DP, Ackermann J, Didcott J, Goldstone J, Kriegler J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, Sachs J and Yacoob J
cases.summary:
The applicant had claimed damages in the High Court for loss of support arising out of the death of her husband in a motor vehcile collision. The claim was based on the Multilateral Motor Vehicle Accidents Fund Act. The High Court found against her on the basis that at common law, marriages contracted in accordance with Islamic law are not lawful marriages. Therefore, because the union was not a valid lawful marriage, she could not claim damages. The court held further that section 39(2) of the Constitution did not empower the court to eliminate this established rule.

The application for leave to appeal the decision directly to the Constitutional Court raised complex issues relating to the jurisdiction of this Court and of the Supreme Court of Appeal. In a unanimous judgment, Justice Chaskalson, expressed the view that the question whether the common law should be developed to allow a party to an Islamic marriage to claim damages for loss of support was of great importance and clearly deserved the attention of a higher court. The central question was which higher court.

Justice Chaskalson noted that, irrespective of which Constitution is said to govern the present case, the appeal falls within the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of Appeal. That court enjoys the power and the expertise to develop the common law in accordance with the spirit, purport and objects of the Bill of Rights. It is thus desirable, in constitutional matters which depend on the development of the common law, for the Constitutional Court to have the benefit of the views of the Supreme Court of Appeal before being called upon to finally dispose of such a matter.

The court held that on a proper interpretation of section 35(3) of the interim Constitution, the Supreme Court of Appeal had jurisdiction to develop the common law in accordance with section 35(3). The Supreme Court of Appeal has always had an inherent jurisdiction to develop the common law to meet the needs of a changing society. However, with the interim and final Constitution, their power to do so must now be exercised in accordance with ”the spirit, purport and objects” of the Bill of Rights.

cases.title: Ex Parte President of the Republic of South Africa: In re Constitutionality of the Liquor Bill
cases.justicesConcurring:
Cameron AJ,  Chaskalson P, Langa DP, Ackermann, Goldstone, Madala, Mokgoro, Ngcobo, O’Regan,
Sachs and Yacoob JJ
cases.summary:
The Liquor Bill was introduced in the National Assembly in 1998. When it was sent to the President for his assent, he declined to grant it. Instead, because he had reservations about its constitutionality, he referred it back to the National Assembly for reconsideration. No amendments were made when it was returned to the President. The President then referred it to the Constitutional Court for a decision on its constitutionality.

Of importance was whether the Bill dealt with ”liquor licences”, which fell within the Schedule 5 exclusive functional area of provincial legislatures, or whether it dealt with issues falling under Schedule 4.

The Court held that in a case of overlap between the concurrent powers and exclusive powers of provinces it may be necessary to establish the substance of the legislation. Cameron AJ concluded that the substance of the Liquor Bill is directed at three objectives:

(a) the prohibition on cross-holdings between the three tiers involved in the liquor trade, namely, producers, distributors and retailers;

(b) the establishment of uniform conditions, in a single system, for the national registration of liquor manufacturers and distributors; and, in a further attempt at establishing national uniformity within the liquor trade;

(c) the prescription of detailed mechanisms to provincial legislatures for the establishment of retail licensing mechanisms.

The Court held that the Bill’s prohibition of cross-holdings falls within the national legislature’s competence to regulate trade. The national system of registration for producers and wholesalers may well also fall within the national legislature’s competence to regulate trade, since the provinces’ exclusive power in relation "liquor licences" was not in the first instance intended to encompass manufacturing and distribution of liquor since these activities are inter-provincial and international. The Court held that in any event national government had succeeded in showing that if the exclusive provincial competence regarding "liquor licences" extends to production and distribution, its interest in maintaining economic unity authorises it to intervene in these areas under section 44(2). However the Court concluded that the Minister failed to show that the national interest required uniform national legislation prescribing detailed mechanisms to provincial legislatures for the establishment of retail licensing mechanisms.

The court held that though South Africa is ”one, soverign, democratic state”, governmental power is not located in national entities alone. For the court, section 40 of the Constitution introduced a new philosophy of cooperative government. In terms of this philosophy, all spheres of government are required to observe and adhere to the principles of cooperative government set out in Chapter 3 of the Constitution. This includes a duty, imposed equally on each sphere of government, not to assume any power or function except those given to them by the Constitution.

cases.title: Premier, Western Cape v President of the Republic of South Africa and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Chaskalson P, Langa DP, Ackermann J, Goldstone J, Kriegler J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, O Regan J, Sachs J and Yacoob J
cases.summary:
Parliament passed the Public Service Laws Amendment Act, 1998, which amended the 1994 Public Servce Act. The amendment was part of a legislative scheme aimed at structural transformation of the public service.

The Western Cape government instituted proceedings before the Constitutional Court to have the Amendment Act declared unconstitutional. They argued that this new legislative scheme infringed on their executive power and limits the autonomy provided to them by the Constitution.

In a unanimous judgment, the Court found that the Constitution expressly requires national legislation to structure the public service. The structure prescribed by the Public Service Amendment Act of 1998 did not infringe the executive authority of provincial Premiers, nor did it encroach upon the functional or institutional integrity of the provinces.

The Western Cape government has not been deprived of any power vested in it under the Constitution or the Western Cape Constitution. Further, the new scheme is rational and cannot be said to be inconsistent with the structure of government contemplated by the Constitution.

The Court, however, found that in one respect the Public Service Amendment Act conferred a power on the national Minister that was inconsistent with the Constitution. The national Minister is empowered to transfer functions from a provincial administration or a provincial department to a national department or other body, or from a national body to a provincial body, after consultation with the MEC concerned. The Court concluded that this permitted the Minister to order the transfers of functions against the wishes of the provincial government. The Court held that this power was inconsistent with the Constitution to the extent that it empowered the Minister to make such transfers without the consent of the Premier.

The court held that the provisions of Chapter 3 of the Constitution are designed to ensure that in the fields of common endeavour, the different spheres of government cooperate with each other to secure the implementation of legislation in which they all have common interest.

Further, the court held that section 41(g) of the Constitution seeks to prevent one sphere of government from using its powers in ways that would undermine other spheres of government, and prevent them from functioning effectively. Therefore, when the national legislature uses its power to establish and structure the public service, it must exercise this power carefully and consistently with the demands of section 41(1)(g) to ensure it does not prevent provinces from carrying out the functions entrusted to them.

cases.title: President of the Republic of South Africa and Others v South African Rugby Football Union and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Chaskalson P, Langa DP, Ackermann J, Goldstone J, Kriegler J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, Sachs J and Yacoob J.
cases.summary:
The applicant issued two notices announcing the appointment of a commission of inquiry into the administration of rugby. The other notice stated that the Commissions Act applied to the commission.

The respondents applied to the High Court for an order to set aside these notices.

The applicant issued two notices announcing the appointment of a commission of inquiry into the administration of rugby. The other notice stated that the Commissions Act applied to the commission.

The respondents applied to the High Court for an order to set aside these notices.

The question before the court was the basis on which courts could review the exercise of presidential powers. Secondly, whether the notices were constitutional.

The court found that the applicant had not handed over his responsibility to the commission. Secondly, the applicant was not obliged to give the respondents a hearing before deciding to appoint the Commission because the decision did not amount to administrative action.

Lastly, the court stated that the applicant could not be forced to give oral evidence in a civil case concerning the performance of his official duties. The applicant was not to be put in the same position as other witnesses because the doctrine of separation of powers sought to protect the office of the applicant.

The court found that the basis on which courts could review presidential powers was because they were executive in nature and that the notices were constitutional.

Section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution which was similar to section 84(2) of the Constitution gave certain powers to the President. These powers were given to the President as the head of state and not as the head of the national executive.

Section 85 of the Constitution also allowed for the President and members of the Executive to collaborate.

The President was entitled to take into consideration the views of members of the Executive but should not act on the advice given unless he had applied his mind.

cases.title: President of the Republic of South Africa and Another v Hugo
cases.justicesConcurring: Goldstone J, Chaskalson P, Mahomeed DP, Ackermann J, Langa J, Madala J, Sachs J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, Didcott J, and Kriegler J.
cases.summary:
The applicant had in terms of his constitutional powers pardoned and granted release to certain mothers in prison with children under the age of 12 years.

The respondent, a single father of a child under the age of 12 challenged the pardon stating that it unfairly discriminated against him and his son on the grounds of sex or gender.

The applicant had in terms of his constitutional powers pardoned and granted release to certain mothers in prison with children under the age of 12 years.

The respondent, a single father of a child under the age of 12 challenged the pardon stating that it unfairly discriminated against him and his son on the grounds of sex or gender.

The question that arose was whether the conduct of the applicant was discriminatory against the respondent. Secondly, what the status of the applicant was in respect to pardoning prisoners under section 82(1).

The court found that the powers afforded to the applicant were executive in nature and as such subject to be reviewed by a court of law.

The pardoning of certain mothers with children under the age of 12 targeted a particular group of prisoners and was discriminatory. However, to determine if the discrimination was unfair the court looked at the impact of the discrimination. The impact on fathers of young children who were not released was found not to significantly compromise the dignity and worth of the men.

The pardon was not discriminatory because the discretion to pardon was with the applicant and the pardon did not prevent fathers from directly applying to the applicant to be pardoned.

Section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution contained non-statutory powers which included the power to grant pardons. These powers did not derive their authority from any legislation.

These powers were not legislative or judicial but executive. This was supported by the heading of section 83 which said, ”Confirmation of executive acts of President”.

When the President was exercising constitutional powers as the head of the executive or head of state, he was acting as an executive organ of government.

The powers afforded to the President under section 82 could be exercised without the concurrence of the cabinet but the President needed to consult with the Executive Deputy Presidents before exercising this power. The President was not however bound by their views.

The majority judgement written by Goldstone J (Chaskalson P, Mahomeed DP, Ackermann J, Langa J, Madala J, Sachs J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J concurring) found that the applicant had discriminated against the respondent. However, this discrimination was justified because it did not significantly affect the dignity and worth of the discriminated group.

Minority judgement written by Didcott J and Kriegler J found that the discrimination was unfair because it discriminated on the grounds of gender or sex. Just because women had suffered from discrimination did not mean that they were entitled to compensatory benefits.

cases.title: Constitutionality of the Mpumalanga Petitions Bill, 2000
cases.justicesConcurring: Langa DP, Chaskalson P, Ackermann J, Kriegler J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, Sachs J, Yacoob J, Du Plessis AJ and Kweyiya AJ.
cases.summary:
The Premier of the Mpumalanga province referred the Petitions Bill to the Constitutional Court so they could decide on the constitutionality of the Bill. The first issue that the Premier raised was whether the legislature was allowed by the Constitution to pass the Petitions Bill. The second issue was whether the legislature was allowed to confer the provincial Speaker the power to make regulations and to determine the date upon which an Act comes into force.

The Premier of the Mpumalanga province referred the Petitions Bill to the Constitutional Court so they could decide on the constitutionality of the Bill.

The first issue that the Premier raised was whether the legislature was allowed by the Constitution to pass the Petitions Bill. The second issue was whether the legislature was allowed to confer the provincial Speaker the power to make regulations and to determine the date upon which an Act comes into force.

Regarding the first issue, the court found that it did not have jurisdiction to decide on the issue because the Premier had not followed the process set out for him in section 121 of the Constitution. This section required the Premier to send the Bill back to the legislature for reconsideration if he had issues with certain parts of the Bill.

Concerning the second issue, the court found that the clauses conferring the power to the Speaker were not unconstitutional. The Speaker was well placed to make the regulations and determine the date on which they came into force.

The legislature is allowed by the Constitution to appoint a functionary to determine when the law comes into force.

The functionary that is normally the best person to make this determination is the head of the executive. There is however no provision in the Constitution that requires that this functionary be the President or Premier.

The allocation of powers to the Speaker to determine the date of commencement of a bill did not implicate the doctrine of separation of powers.

cases.title: Matatiele Municipality and Others v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others (1)
cases.justicesConcurring: Ngcobo J, Langa CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Madala J, Mokgor J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Sachs J, Van der Westhuizen, Skweyia J and Yacoob J
cases.summary:
The applicants challenged the constitutionality of the Twelfth Amendment and the Cross-Boundary Municipalities Laws Repeal and Related Matters Act. In terms of these laws, the boundary that separated KwaZulu-Natal from the Eastern Cape was changed. In doing so the area that previously fell under the Matatiele Local Municipality was transferred from KwaZulu- Natal to the Eastern Cape and new municipal boundaries were created as a consequence.

The applicants challenged the constitutionality of the Twelfth Amendment and the Cross-Boundary Municipalities Laws Repeal and Related Matters Act. In terms of these laws, the boundary that separated KwaZulu-Natal from the Eastern Cape was changed. In doing so the area that previously fell under the Matatiele Local Municipality was transferred from KwaZulu- Natal to the Eastern Cape and new municipal boundaries were created as a consequence.

The issues before the court were that firstly, the above-mentioned laws changed the boundaries without complying with the procedure as set out in the Constitution and that secondly, by doing so Parliament took over the functions that the Constitution had reserved for an independent authority which was the Municipal Demarcation Board.

The court found that the Municipal Demarcation Board was an independent authority vested with the power to draw municipal boundaries. In giving this board the power, the Constitution sought to prevent political interference in the process of creating provincial boundaries. However, this power was limited by the authority of Parliament to draw provincial boundaries and so the Twelfth Amendment did not violate the Constitution.

Secondly, the court raised its doubt regarding the process followed. In light of this, the court postponed the matter so it could conduct investigations.

The Constitution demands that each provincial government establish municipalities that are consistent with certain national legislation, The Structures Act. A provincial government could not establish a municipality in another province.

The authority of Parliament to redraw boundaries and interfere with municipal boundaries was supported by the Constitution.

The majority judgement written by Ngcobo J (Langa CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Madala J, Mokgor J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Sachs J and Van der Westhuizen concurring) found that the Twelfth Amendment was not invalid but the court had questions regarding the process followed. The court postponed the matter to investigate.

Skweyia J and Yacoob J both agreed with the judgement above but disagreed with the postponement. They found that it was not in the interest of justice to postpone the case for investigation because the benefit to the applicants was not enough to warrant further delay.

cases.title: Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association of South Africa and Another: In re Ex Parte President of the Republic of South Africa and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: http://www.saflii.org/za/cases/ZACC/2000/1.html
cases.summary:
The South African Medicines and Medical Devices Regulatory Authority Act 132 of 1998 gave the President the power to determine the date to bring it (the Act) into operation by proclamation.

The President issued a proclamation to bring the Act into operation, which proclamation was published in the Government Gazette on 30 April 1999. However the system of schedules necessary for the Act to be effective was not in place when the proclamation was issued (the same time that Act brought into operation).

The President, amongst others, realising this error, approached the courts, to set aside the decision to issue the proclamation and bring the Act into operation. The President was given the power to bring an Act (governing, amongst other things, the control of medical substances) into operation.

The Act repealed parts of older legislation which classified medical substances and thereby regulated those substances; and accordingly, the new Act required the replacement schedules to be in place in order for it to work (be effective).

The President issued a proclamation to bring the Act into operation; however the system of schedules upon which the Act was based and functioned was not in place by this time.
