The Constitutional Court found that the proclamation issued by the President was premature, irrational and therefore invalid because the decision to issue the proclamation and bring the Act into operation was not rationally connected to (i.e. would not have been successful in) making the Act an effective source of law without the schedules in place.

The consequence of the Court’s reasoning and application of the Constitution in this case is that all public power, including power exercised by the President and National Executive, must both be lawful and rational in order for the exercise of the power to be consistent with the constitutional principle of legality and to be valid.

(1) The Court confirmed that there was only one system of law under the 1996 Constitution and that the Constitution is supreme. Therefore, the common law must be shaped and defined by the Constitution and cannot be separated and applied independently of the Constitution.

(2) Chaskalson P explained that the principle of legality (under section 1(c) of the Constitution (‘the rule of law’)) requires that all exercise of public power must be both lawful and rational (non-arbitrary). Rationality means that an exercise of power must be related to, amongst other things, the purpose for which the power was given (and therefore also be non-arbitrary). It is irrelevant that the person or body exercising the power acted in good faith when determining whether an exercise of power was rational or not. The lawfulness and rationality requirements are minimum requirements applicable to all exercises of public power; if the minimum requirements are not met, then the exercise of the power is invalid.

(3) Specifically, the Court determined that the President’s decision – to bring the Act into operation through the proclamation – was irrational. The decision to bring the Act into force would have to have been for the purpose of making the Act an effective source of law; but without the schedules in place to classify the medical substances etc, the Act could not be implemented and was ineffective even if brought into operation. Therefore, the purpose for which the President exercised the power could not be achieved by the exercise of the power itself and was irrational.

cases.title: In re: National Education Policy Bill No 83 of 1995
cases.justicesConcurring: Chaskalson P, Mahomed DP, Ackermann J, Didcott J, Kentridge AJ, Kriegler J, Langa J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, and Sachs J
cases.summary:
The Speaker of the National Assembly referred a dispute to the Constitutional Court regarding the constitutionality of certain provisions of the National Education Bill. The National Party, the Democratic Party and the Inkatha Freedom Party took issue with the Bill and argued that the Bill had the effect of empowering the Minister to impose the national government’s policies on the provinces.

The main challenge to the Bill was based on the argument that it required the provinces to amend their legislation to conform to national education policy, and thereby empowered the Minister to impose national education policy on the provinces. The Court rejected this contention and held that the Bill neither imposed an obligation on the provinces to follow national education policy nor empowered the Minister to require the provinces to adopt national policy nor to amend their own legislation to conform with national policy.

The Court held that provinces must comply with national standards which have been formulated in accordance with the Constitution and lawfully made applicable to them. The effect of the Bill was to give the provinces an opportunity of addressing situations where the standards of education provision, delivery and performance did not comply with national standards or the Constitution. The Bill further suggests remedial action that should be taken, even when the national standards have been formulated but have not yet been made the subject of legislation. The Bill thereby prevented the national government from acting unilaterally, without allowing the provinces this opportunity.

A further challenge to the Bill was that it required Members of Executive Councils and their administrations to participate in structures, provide information and promote a national policy. This challenge was rejected. The Court held that the only reasonable way in which concurrent powers could be exercised was through consultation with and co-operation between the national executive and the provincial executives.

The Court analyzed the relationship between the powers of the provincial legislatures and the powers of Parliament. The court held that if there is a conflict between a provincial law and an Act of Parliament, the Constitution provides for the resolution of that conflict by giving priority either to Acts of Parliament or to provincial laws, depending on the circumstances. If there is such a conflict, the provisions of the law which are given priority must be enforced in all respects. The other law is not invalidated and, for as long as that inconsistency endures, it is inoperative and ineffective only to the extent of the inconsistency but must be implemented in all other respects.

cases.title: Western Cape Provincial Government and Others In Re: DVB Behuising (Pty) Limited v North West Provincial Government and Another
cases.justicesConcurring:
Ngcobo J. (Majority judgement)   
Madala J.; Goldstone J.; O’Regan J.; Sachs J.  (dissenting judgment)
cases.summary:
The applicants made an application for confirmation of an order declaring that the repeal of the Proclamation R293 of 1962, issued in terms of the Native Administration Act, 38 of 1927 by section 6 of North West Local Government Laws Amendment Act, 7 of 1998 was unconstitutional. The Proclamation was issued in terms of the Native Administration Act, 38 of 1927. It made provisions for the establishment of a special kind of township by the Minister of Bantu Administration and Development for African citizens in areas of land held by the South African Native Trust which was established by the Native Trust and Land Act, 18 of 1936. The legislature of the North West Province then enacted the North West Local Government Laws Amendment Act of which section 6 aimed to repeal the Proclamation in its entirety. The applicant, DVB Behuising (Pty) Limited (DVB), challenged the constitutional validity of section 6 of North West Local Government Laws Amendment Act, contending that the intended repeal of the Proclamation was beyond the legislative competence of the North West.

The issue before the court was whether the North West Provincial legislature had the authority to enact the North West Local Government Laws Amendment Act. Section 6 of the Act was aimed at repealing the Proclamation in its entirety. The applicant challenged the constitutional validity of section 6 of the Act and argued that the intended repeal of the Proclamation was beyond the legislative authority of the North West. The result, it claimed, was to make it impossible for persons to whom it had sold houses in a township established under the Proclamation, to have their deeds of grant registered, or to get bank loans on their properties. The Constitutional Court refused to confirm the order of invalidity made by the High Court, except insofar as it related to provisions concerning registration of title. The court held that the Proclamation dealt with various matters some of which included regional planning and development, rural and urban development and local government and others related to the registration of land tenure rights. The court held that although the province had the power to repeal the Proclamation insofar as it related to regional planning and development and local government, it did not have the authority to repeal provisions relating to the registration of titles.

The Constitutional Court refused to confirm the order of invalidity made by the High Court, except insofar as it related to provisions concerning registration of title. The court held that although the province had the power to repeal the Proclamation insofar as it related to regional planning and development and local government, it did not have the authority to repeal provisions relating to the registration of titles. It stated that the matter had to be regulated by the national sphere of government in order to provide uniformity throughout the country. It was therefore competent for the North West to repeal the whole Proclamation, save for those provisions that dealt with registration of title. The court held further that repeal of the Proclamation would not have a negative impact on anyone since the holders of deeds of grant were protected by the deeds registration laws.

In its dissenting judgment, the court disagreed with the majority and held that, the Provincial legislature had the power to repeal the whole of the Proclamation since its land registration provisions were related to its planning provisions. It emphasised that the main purpose of the Proclamation was to establish and administer racially and ethnically exclusive townships. Although section 6 provided for the establishment of deeds registries for the registration of deeds of grant and thus created certain land tenure rights, it had to be read within the framework of the whole of the Proclamation, which was mainly aimed at the administration and control of black people. The function of the Proclamation was to regulate land use as part of provincial planning, and this was within the provincial legislative competence. The court held that the land registration provisions were validly repealed along with the rest of the Proclamation and accordingly declined to confirm any part of the order of the High Court.

cases.title: President of the Republic of South Africa: In re Constitutionality of the Liquor Bill
cases.justicesConcurring: Cameron AJ
cases.summary:
The President of the Republic referred the Liquor Bill passed by Parliament in November 1998, to the Constitutional Court to decide on its constitutionality in March 1999. In doing this, the President for the first time invoked his power under section 79 of the Constitution to refer a Bill to the Court if he had reservations about its constitutionality. In this instance, the President expressed reservations about the constitutionality of the Bill to the extent that the Bill dealt with the registration for the manufacture, wholesale distribution and retail sale of liquor. As the provisions would be intruding on the provincial legislatures’ exclusive powers regarding liquor licenses. The President of the Constitutional Court invited interested political parties and organs of state to make representations concerning the constitutionality of the Bill. The Western Cape Provincial Government and the Minister of Trade and Industry responded and appeared before the Court.

The President of the Constitutional Court invited interested political parties and organs of state to make representations concerning the constitutionality of the Liquor Bill passed by Parliament in November 1998. The Western Cape Provincial Government and the Minister of Trade and Industry responded and appeared before the Court. The court had to determine whether the Bill was unconstitutional. The Minister of Trade and Industry argued that the Bill was not a liquor licensing measure because the matters it regulated fell within the national legislature’s competence and its provisions that dealt with liquor licensing were related to its goal of national competencies. The Minister argued further that even if the Bill infringed on the provinces’ exclusive powers it was justified in terms of section 44(2) of the Constitution. The provisions of section 44(2) allowed the national government to intervene into the area of exclusive provincial legislative competence where this was necessary for certain purposes, which included the maintenance of economic unity. The court held that the Liquor Bill was unconstitutional in that the national government had not succeeded in justifying the Bill’s intervention in the field of retail liquor sales, nor in the case of micro-manufacturers of liquor, whose operations are essentially provincial.

In a unanimous decision, the court held that the Liquor Bill was unconstitutional in that the national government had not succeeded in justifying the Bill’s intervention in the field of retail liquor sales, nor in the case of micro-manufacturers of liquor, whose operations are essentially provincial. The court considered the exclusive provincial legislative competencies against the background of the Constitution’s distribution of governmental power. The court held that provinces were accorded power primarily in regard to matters which may be regulated within each province, though subject to being overruled by the national government in terms of section 44(2) of the Constitution. The Court held that national government had succeeded in showing that if the exclusive provincial competence regarding liquor licences extended to production and distribution, its interest in maintaining economic unity authorised it to intervene in those areas under section 44(2).

cases.title: Executive Council of the Province of the Western Cape v Minister for Provincial Affairs and Constitutional Development and Another, Executive Council of KwaZulu-Natal v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others
cases.justicesConcurring:
Ngcobo J. (Majority judgement)
O'Regan J. (Dissenting judgement) 
Mokgoro J.; Cameron AJ. (concurring dissenting judgment of O'Regan J)
cases.summary:
The applicants applied for direct access with an application alleging that the Government: Municipal Structures Act as a whole, and certain sections of the Act in particular, violated Chapter 7 of the Constitution which deals with local government. As part of the process of restructuring local government in South Africa, Parliament passed the Local Government: Municipal Structures Act. They applied for direct access to the Constitutional Court because the matter was of significant national importance, and the issues were restricted to legal arguments rather than factual disputes. The two cases were heard together because the issues raised in them significantly overlapped.

The applicants applied for direct access with an application alleging that the Government: Municipal Structures Act as a whole, and certain sections of the Act in particular, violated Chapter 7 of the Constitution which deals with local government. The Constitution empowered the national level of government to establish criteria for determining whether an area should have a metropolitan council. These criteria were prescribed by the Structures Act, sections 4 and 5 of which allowed the national Minister for Provincial and Local Government to apply the criteria in order to declare areas as metropolitan areas, and to fix points within those areas around which the boundaries must be drawn. The applicants argued that the declaration of metropolitan areas was a provincial power being related to the power to establish municipalities. The court rejected the applicant’s argument and held that Chapter 7 of the Constitution divided powers and functions relating to the structure and control of local government between different organs of state. It held further that the national level of government had no powers in respect of matters other than those allocated to it by Chapter 7. The court decided that the Structures Act was not unconstitutional, but that five of the sections of the Act were inconsistent with the Constitution and were accordingly invalid.

The court decided that the Structures Act was not unconstitutional, but that five of the sections of the Act were inconsistent with the Constitution and were accordingly invalid. The court rejected the applicants argument that the declaration of metropolitan areas was a provincial power that was related to the power to establish municipalities and decided that the application of the criteria formed part of the function of boundary determination which the Constitution vests in the Demarcation Board, and not the national or provincial levels of government, and that sections 4 and 5 were unconstitutional for this reason.

In its dissenting decision, the Court held that sections 4 and 5 were constitutional. The court found that the Constitution did not specify who could apply the criteria to determine which areas must have metropolitan municipalities. National legislation could, therefore, deal with this matter as envisaged by section 164 of the Constitution, and the Minister could be delegated with the task. The Demarcation Board’s constitutional role was limited to drawing boundaries.

cases.title: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union and Another v Garvas and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ
cases.summary:
The applicants organised a gathering of thousands of people to register certain employment-related concerns of its members within the security industry. The gathering was the conclusion of a delayed strike action in the course of which about 50 people allegedly lost their lives. It was also alleged that during the strike action private property and property of the City was damaged. In preparation for the gathering, the applicants took steps to meet the procedural requirements set out in the Regulation of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993. They gave notice of the gathering to the local authority and appointed marshals to manage the crowd. It also advised its members to refrain from any unlawful and violent behaviour and requested the local authority to clear the roads of vehicles and erect barricades along the prescribed route on the day of the gathering. In spite of these precautionary measures, the gathering resulted in riot damage. Several people were injured and about 39 others were arrested. The respondents claim that as a consequence of this gathering their shops were vandalised and looted, and their property was damaged. As a result, the respondents instituted action for damages against the applicants.

The applicants made an application to have the Supreme Court of Appeal order declaring section 11(2) of the Regulation of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993 constitutionally valid upheld. The Act imposed a statutory liability on the organiser of a gathering for riot damage resulting from that gathering. The applicants argued that the section was irrational, and it constituted an unjustifiable limitation of the right to freedom of assembly in section 17 of the Constitution. The court held that the law is aimed at affording victims effective recourse where a gathering became destructive and resulted in injury, loss of property or life. It held that the justification provided for by the law was viable and that the limitation on the right to freedom of assembly in section 17 of the Constitution was reasonable and justifiable. The court further emphasised that the reasonable steps taken on the one hand and reasonable foreseeability on the other hand were inter-linked. Organisers were obliged at all times to take reasonable steps to prevent all reasonably foreseeable conduct that caused damage and the reasonable steps must be of the kind that render the conduct causing damage unforeseeable.

The court held that the right to freedom of assembly is central to our constitutional democracy. It exists primarily to give a voice to the powerless. This includes groups that do not have political or economic power, and other vulnerable persons. It held that the justification provided for by the law was viable and that the limitation on the right to freedom of assembly in section 17 of the Constitution was reasonable and justifiable. The court further emphasised that the reasonable steps taken on the one hand and reasonable foreseeability on the other hand were inter-linked. Organisers were obliged at all times to take reasonable steps to prevent all reasonably foreseeable conduct that caused damage and the reasonable steps must be of the kind that render the conduct causing damage unforeseeable.

In a concurring judgment, Jafta J held that the appeal should be dismissed, on the basis that the applicants had failed to prove that the law limits the right to freedom of assembly, or that the defence that it creates is irrational.

cases.title: Hotz and Others v University of Cape Town
cases.summary:
The applicants applied for leave to appeal against the decision of the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) upholding a final interdict against five protesters who had participated in the “Shackville” protest at the University of Cape Town (UCT), as part of the national #FeesMustFall movement. The group of protesters created a shack on UCT’s premises in the middle of Residence Road. They further painted slogans on the War Memorial at the campus and removed and burnt portraits and paintings from buildings on the campus. Roads into and around the campus were blockaded and attempts by the university management to move the protests to another location failed. The university obtained a final interdict from the High Court against several protestors and in addition to granting the final interdict against those protesters, the High Court ordered them to pay the university’s costs jointly and severally, including the costs of two counsel. The applicants challenged the SCA’s decision on the merits regarding the granting of the final interdict.

The applicants applied for leave to appeal against the decision of the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) upholding a final interdict against five protesters who had participated in the “Shackville” protest at the University of Cape Town (UCT), as part of the national #FeesMustFall movement. The applicants challenged the SCA’s decision on the merits regarding the granting of the final interdict. The matter raised certain constitutional issues which included the rights to education, freedom of expression, to assembly, demonstration, picket and petition as well as the right to freedom of association. In a unanimous decision, the court held that the applicants started a protest seeking to defend their rights including the rights to education in terms of section 29 of the Constitution and to assemble and demonstrate in terms of section 17 of the Constitution. Their right to assemble and demonstrate ended when their demonstration or protest became violent, thus violating the rights not only of the University but also of others at the campus. It held further that the protestors’ conduct went beyond the boundary of a peaceful and non-violent protest. The University had no choice but to approach the High Court for an order restraining the group from conducting themselves unlawfully during their protest.

In a unanimous decision, the court held that applicant’s right to assemble and demonstrate ended when their demonstration or protest became violent, thus violating the rights not only of the University but also of others at the campus. The court held that the protestors’ conduct went beyond the boundary of a peaceful and non-violent protest. The Constitutional Court upheld the appeal only against the order of the SCA upholding the High Court’s order on costs on the basis that the High Court failed exercise discretion judicially in the constitutional context. The court then held that the costs order of the High Court against the applicants which were confirmed by the SCA, were to be set aside and each party was ordered to pay its own costs in the High Court, the SCA and the Constitutional Court.

cases.title: Mlungwana and Others v S and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Petse AJ
cases.summary:
The applicants made an application for the confirmation of an order of the constitutional invalidity made by the High Court, Western Cape Division. The High Court declared section 12(1)(a) of the Regulation of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993 (Act) unconstitutional and invalid. This section made it a criminal offence to convene an assembly of more than 15 people without first notifying the responsible officer of a municipality, even if such a gathering is peaceful and unarmed. The applicants travelled as a group to picket at the Cape Town Civic Centre to voice their dissatisfaction with inadequate sanitation facilities in Khayelitsha. The picket was peaceful and unarmed, but grew in size at the venue as more people joined in. The applicants were then arrested and charged for contravening section 12(1)(a) of the Act and charged with the offence of failing to give notice of an assembly in terms of section 12(1)(a).

The applicants made an application for the confirmation of an order of the constitutional invalidity made by the High Court, Western Cape Division. The High Court declared section 12(1)(a) of the Regulation of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993 unconstitutional and invalid.

The applicants travelled as a group of 15 to picket at the Cape Town Civic Centre but their number grew in size at the venue as more people joined. The applicants were arrested and charged for contravening section 12(1)(a) of the Act and charged with the offence of failing to give notice of an assembly in terms of section 12(1)(a). The respondents argued that the purpose of criminalising the failure to give notice was to ensure that municipalities and the police could prepare for large assemblies and in so doing reduce violence at protests. The court held that while these purpose for the notice was important, the state in responding to unfortunate incidents at assemblies, cannot employ heavy-handed measures that excessively limited the right to assemble peacefully and unarmed. The court held that criminalising the failure by the convener of a gathering to give notice of an assembly of more than 15 people limits the right to assemble peacefully and unarmed, which is rooted in section 17 of the Constitution. This is because criminalisation deters the exercise of the right to assemble, and deterrence by its very nature limits the exercise of this right.

In a unanimous decision, the court confirmed the High Court’s declaration of invalidity. The Constitutional Court held that this limitation to the right to assemble is unjustifiable. The right to assemble peacefully and unarmed is central to South Africa’s constitutional democracy. This was because criminalisation deters the use of the right to assemble, and deterrence by its very nature limits the exercise of this right. The court held further that the constitutional invalidity of section 12(1)(a) must in no way be understood to imply that the right to assemble can be exercised in any way other than peacefully and unarmed. People convening and participating in a gathering who intend to act violently forfeit their right. However, for as long as they act within the limits prescribed in section 17 of the Constitution, they will be assured of constitutional protection.

cases.title: Association of Mineworkers and Construction and Others v Royal Bafokeng Platinum Limited and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ
cases.summary:
The applicants made an application for the reinstatement of 103 of its members who were retrenched by the respondent on 18 September 2015. The applicant’s members were retrenched following a retrenchment agreement that was concluded by the respondents and two other unions at the mine, the National Union of Mines (NUM) and United Association of South Africa (UASA). The retrenchments took place after the respondents reccognised NUM as the majority union within the company. Both the applicants and UASA became the minority unions. The result was that the minority unions, would be granted organisational and bargaining rights by the respondent. However, the applicants, unlike UASA, were not recognised for bargaining purposes. The retrenchment agreement was decided to the exclusion of the applicants even though it extended to its members and the agreement was made in accordance with section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act. Subsequently, applicants then challenged its members’ dismissals.

The applicants made an application for the reinstatement of 103 of its members who were retrenched by the respondent on 18 September 2015. Following an agreement made by the respondents and two other unions to the exclusion of the applicant. The agreement was made in accordance with section 23(1)(d) of the LRA. The applicants then challenged the constitutionality of the section as well as the dismissal of its members. The applicants argued that the collective agreement was constitutionally offensive, as it allowed for a majority union to conclude a collective agreement concerning a retrenchment process to the exclusion of minority unions in the workplace. The applicants proposed that the section should be interpreted to allow for inclusive consultation or be struck down accordingly. The court had to determine whether there were any constitutional rights that were being limited and if there were, whether the limitation was justifiable. The court held that the freedom of association challenge by the applicant failed as this would require the court to adopt a proposition that the right to freely associate meant that every union must be truly equal, and enjoy each and every statutory entitlement, regardless of its size. It held further that an employee had the right to join a trade union of their preference however, this did not entail the right that the preferred union be empowered in every way they desired.

The court held that the freedom of association challenge by the applicant failed as this required the court to adopt a proposition that the right to freedom of association intended that every union must be truly equal, and enjoy each and every statutory entitlement, regardless of its size. It held further that an employee had the right to join a trade union of their preference however, this did not entail the right that the preferred union be empowered in every way they desired.

The dissenting judgment held that section 18 of the Constitution conferred the right to freedom of association upon everyone. In the context of labour relations this right enables workers to join unions of their own choice. This right is fortified by the right to form or join a trade union of one’s choice guaranteed by section 23(2)(a) of the Constitution. It held further that there would have been no justification for placing majoritarianism beyond the rights guaranteed by the Constitution. Nor could it be said that majoritarianism constitutes a reasonable and justifiable limitation of those rights, including the right to freedom of association. The court said that there would have been no justification for placing majoritarianism beyond the rights guaranteed by the Constitution. The court concluded that the limitation of the applicants’ right to freedom of association was neither reasonable nor justifiable. This was because there were no other reasons were raised for that limitation. This was because there were no other reasons were raised for that limitation.

cases.title: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union and Others v Chamber of Mines of South Africa and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Cameron J
cases.summary:
The applicants applied to court seeking leave to appeal against a judgment and order of the Labour Appeal Court which held that a collective agreement was binding even on employees who were not members of the unions party to the agreement provided that those unions had the majority of the employees as their members in the workplace. The applicants argued that, section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act unjustifiably limited its members’ rights to fair labour practices, including the right to bargain collectively through the applicant, the right to strike and the right to freedom of association.

The applicants argued that, section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act unjustifiably limited its members’ rights to fair labour practices, including the right to bargain collectively through the applicant, the right to strike and the right to freedom of association. The issue before the court was whether a collective agreement concluded between the Chamber of Mines, on behalf of certain gold mining companies and the majority trade unions could be extended to bind the members of the applicant even though they had majority representation at certain individual mines.

The collective agreement was extended in terms of section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act (LRA). It stipulated that a collective agreement was binding even on employees who were not members of the unions party to the agreement provided that those unions had the majority of the employees as their members in the workplace. The court held that any infringement of the right to strike was reasonable and justifiable based on the principle of majoritarianism. The Court held that any infringement of the right to strike was reasonable and justifiable based on the principle of majoritarianism which, in this context, benefitted orderly collective bargaining. That majoritarianism was functional to enhanced collective bargaining was internationally recognized. The Court found that the conclusion of an agreement under section 23(1)(d) constituted the exercise of public power and was subject to review under the principle of legality. The principle required that all exercises of public power including non-administrative action follow minimum standards of lawfulness. For these reasons, the Court decided that the agreement validly extended to the applicant’s members and the relevant statutory provisions were constitutionally consistent.

The court in a unanimous decision held that the statutory structures that enforced the majoritarian system allowed minority unions freedom of association. Minority unions had recruiting rights which the applicant had as well as organisational and deduction rights. The court held further that the applicants had bargaining rights although they lost the right to strike while the agreement was in force. The court said none of the non-signatory unions or employees lost any of their organisational and collective bargaining entitlements. The court held that through affording these rights, this meant that the LRA, though premised on majoritarianism, was not a tool of oppression and did not supress minority unions. It held that the Act gave enough scope for minority unions to organise within the workforce and canvas support to challenge the domination of established unions. The court held that section 23(1)(d) promoted and served the goals of collective bargaining, which was a legitimate legislative end.

cases.title: New Nation Movement NPC and Others v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Justice Cameron, Justice Froneman, Justice Jafta, Justice Khampepe, Justice Madlanga,  Acting Justice Mathopo, Justice Mhlantla, Justice Theron, Acting Justice Victor
cases.summary:
The four applicants, except for the second applicant, all involved Non-Governmental organisations or associations. The second applicant, a natural person described herself as a representative of Khoi and San communities and a princess of the Korona Royal Household of the Khoi and the San First Nation. It appears that the objectives of the applicants to an extent were similiar and they were essentially averse to joining or forming a political party and believed that the current electoral system infinged on their constitutional rights.The applicants applied to the Western Cape High Court on an urgent basis to declare the Electoral Act 73 of 1998 unconstitutional to the extent that an individual could not contest tha national and provincial elections. The matter was heard on an urgent basis as the national elections were to be held in a few weeks.

The Western Cape High Court dismissed the matter on 17 April 2019 and the aApplicants then urgently applied for direct leave to appeal the Western Cape High Court judgment to the Constitutional Court on 19 April 2019. In light of the pending elections, the Constitutional Court only heard arguments on the question of the urgency of the matter on 2 May 2019. The Constitutional Court held that the Applicants did not make out a case for urgency and postponed the matter to be argued on 15 August 2019.

The New Nation Movement judgment declared the Electoral Act of 1998 unconstitutional, to the extent that individuals can only be elected to the National Assembly and Provincial Legislature through membership of their political parties. It is, however, important to note that the Constitutional Court did not consider what electoral system would be more appropriate, as this falls within the mandate of Parliament, and hence the Order was suspended for two years in order for Parliament to remedy the defect.

The constitutional challenge in the judgment was essentially distilled to two critical aspects. Firstly, the meaning of section 19(3)(b) of the Constitution, which states that “Every adult citizen has the right (b) to stand for public office and if, elected, to hold office” had to be determined. Secondly, the Court had to determine whether section 57A of the Electoral Act, read with schedule 1A of the Act (which, in effect, required a citizen to be a member of a political party to contest national and provincial elections) unjustifiably limited an individual’s right to freedom of association, provided for in section 18 of the Constitution. The question was approached holistically by Madlanga J who held that that section 19(3)(b) of the Constitution must be read not only in conjunction with the right to freedom of association but also with other political rights in s 19 of the Constitution. Madlanga J held that the choice to form a political party in terms of section 19(1) equally includes the right not to join a political party. If section 19(3)(b) is read that only by joining a political party an individual can exercise the right to stand for public office, then it is in conflict with section 19(1), which equally protects the choice not to join a political party.

On the second aspect concerning the right to freedom of association, Madlanga J held that on consideration of foreign and international law, the right equally includes the right not to be forced to join an association. The question then turned to whether the limitation of the right to freedom of association by the Electoral Act could be justified as a reasonable limitation in terms of section 36 of the Constitution. The majority however found that the respondents were unable to justify on evidence the limitation and therefore the Electoral Act was held to be unconstitutional, to the extent that it excluded independent candidates to contest national and provincial elections.

In the Constitution, section 1 refers to the founding values of the Constitution. These values emphasise that the Republic of South Africa is “one, sovereign, democratic state” which is founded on various core value such as human dignity, non-racialism, supremacy of the Constitution and a multi-party system of democratic governance. It is important to note that these founding values form the premise of our constitutional order and in terms of the Constitution a high threshold is required to amend these provisions.

In this judgment section 1 (d) of the Constitution was specifically considered as the Western Cape High Court held that the founding values of section 1(d) do not support the applicant’s case. Section 1(d) of the Constitution provides that the founding values of the Republic include: ”Universal adult suffrage, a national common voters roll, regular elections and a multi-party system of democratic government, to ensure accountability, responsiveness and openness”. The applicants argued that section 1(d) of the Constitution cannot be read as requiring an exclusively party based proportional representation system.

The majority of the Constitutional Court on considering this aspect, held that section 1(d) of the Constitution says nothing about the exclusivity of multi-party representation. A multi-party democracy allows different political groups to organise and participate in an election but this does not mean only political groups can do so. In this regard the majority relied on the Constitutional Court judgment of United Democratic Movement v President of the Republic of South Africa.

Due to the importance of political rights with the South African context, section 19(3)(b) needed to be interpreted generously and not restrictively.

Section 19 (1)

enables a person not to form or join a political party and this should be protected as a political choice. Once a person is made to join a political party to exercise their section 19(3)(b) right, that means that the choice afforded to them by s 19(1) is no longer there. The Electoral Act limits section 19(3)(b) because it makes it impossible for candidates to stand for political office without first being members of a political party. This limitation was not justified and it also was not reasonable. The Electoral Act was unconstitutional to the extent that it limited sections 19(1) and 19(3)(b).

The dissenting judgment was written by Froneman J, who agreed that leave to appeal should have been grantedn but disagreed with the reasoning and outcome on the merits of the appeal. Essentially Froneman J disagreed with the majority’s interpretation of ”to stand for public office and, if elected, to hold office”in section 19(3)(b) of the Constitution and held that it was not shown that the Constitution prescribes something other than political parties in its fundamental multi-party system of democratic governance.

cases.title: Khosa and Others v Minister of Social Development and Others, Mahlaule and Another v Minister of Social Development
cases.justicesConcurring:
Mokgoro J (Chaskalson CJ, Langa DCJ, Goldstone J, Moseneke J, O’Regan J and Yacoob J) (majority) 
Ngcobo J (Madala J) (minority)
cases.summary:
The applicants challenged certain provisions of the Social Assistance Act 59 of 1992 which disqualified persons who are not South African citizens from receiving certain welfare grants. The applicants were both permanent residents. (Section 3(c) reserved social grants for aged South Africans; and sections 4(b)(ii) and 4B(b)(ii) reserved child-support grants and care dependency grants respectively for South African citizens only.)

Are non-citizens enttiled the fundamental right to social welfare as enshrined in section 27 of the Constitution? And if so, it is a reasonable and justifiable limitation to exclude non-citizens from programmes that give effect to that right based on their non-citizen status?

The Constitutional Court agreed that – whereas some rights in the Bill of Rights are limited citizens only – the right to social security enshrined in section 27(1)(c) of the Constitution is extended to ‘everyone’, which includes permanent resident non-citizens. Furthermore, the majority found that the provisions disqualifying non-citizens from social grants were unreasonable and therefore unconstitutional and invalid.

In order to resolve the unconstitutionality, the Court ‘read-in’ (instructed that the term be included in the provision as if written-in originally) the words ‘or permanent resident’ after the word ‘citizen’ in each of the challenged sections.

The Court concluded that non-citizens, namely permanent residents, are entitled to the right to social welfare under section 27(1) for the following reasons: (i) Section 27(1) entitles the right to ‘everyone’ which is a wide term and without distinction for citizenship or other status ; (ii) The Constitution explicitly states that the Bill of Rights enshrines the rights of ‘all people in our country’; and (iii) Whilst other constitutional rights are self-restricted to citizens only (e.g. sections 19, 21(3), 21(4) and 22), section 27(1) contains no similar restrictions, indicating that it is not limited to citizens or other classes (groups) of persons only.

The majority found that the exclusion of permanent residents from the welfare scheme was not reasonable and was discriminatory and unfair given the ‘fundamental’ impact that the exclusion would have on non-citizens: it would force them to the margins of society and deprive them of the ability to enjoy other constitutional rights.

The minority found that section 3(c) to be a reasonable limitation of the right of access to social security, reasoning that: (i) the state has insufficient resources and was therefore entitled to prioritise its citizens in making resources available; (ii) that the disqualification was for the legitimate purposes of encouraging self-sufficiency in immigrants, and avoiding incentivising immigration to South Africa; and (iii) the limitation was only temporary (and therefore not extreme) as it was possible for the permanent residents to naturalise (become citizens) after five years and access the welfare grants reserved for citizens. The dissent agreed that the provisions relating to children were unconstitutional.

cases.title: Kaunda and Others v President of the Republic of South Africa
cases.justicesConcurring:
Chaskalson CJ (Langa DCJ, Moseneke J, Skweyiya J, van der Westhuizen J and Yacoob J) (majority)
Ngcobo J (concurrence) 
Sachs J (concurrence) 
O’Regan J (Mokgoro J) (minority/dissent)
cases.summary:
The applicants were 69 South African citizens being held in Zimbabwe on a variety of charges. The applicants feared being extradited to Equatorial Guinea where several other South Africans had recently been arrested and accused of being mercenaries and plotting a coup against the President of Equatorial Guinea; and ultimately not receiving a fair trial in general and in Equatorial Guinea specifically.

The applicants approached the South African courts to compel the South African government to provide them with diplomatic protection, namely through having them extradited to South Africa.

The main question in the case was whether, under international law or the Constitution, the government has a legal duty to provide diplomatic protection to (take action or steps to assist and protect) South African nationals abroad (i.e. who are arrested and imprisoned in a foreign country). The applicants approached the Constitutional Court, asking for an order to compel the government to provide such diplomatic assistance to them after they had been arrested and detained in Zimbabwe. The applicants were all South African citizens.

A majority of the Constitutional Court determined that: South African nationality entitles a person to ask the government to provide them with diplomatic protection; but that the government is generally only obliged to consider (and properly respond) to such requests, not to take the steps requested. The Court noted that nationality is generally gained when a person becomes a citizen.

(i) ‘Nationality’ and ‘citizenship’ are different but related concepts. Under international law, a person will have the nationality of a state (i.e. will be a national of the state) if there is a sufficiently close and genuine link between the person and that state. Generally, gaining citizenship of a state results in a person gaining that state’s nationality, but not always.

(ii) Nationality entitles a person to request the state to provide them with diplomatic protection. Nationals are not permitted to raise international law protections themselves against other states, and are therefore obliged to seek protection through their state. The state, namely South Africa, is not obliged to provide such protection as it has a discretion in how to manage international relations, including whether to take action and what action (if any). Therefore, citizens/nationals do not have an enforceable right to diplomatic protection.

(iii) Citizens/nationals are not necessarily entitled to the rights in the South African Bill of Rights beyond the South African borders because the South African Constitution does not bind other states; but the South African state remains bound by the Constitution and must act consistently with it, including in considering requests for diplomatic protection.

O’Regan J found that there is a duty on the state, in terms of section 3(2) of the Constitution, to provide diplomatic protection to its nationals in order to prevent the violation of their fundamental human rights under international law; but that because the duty can only be carried out by the state through its foreign policies and action, the state must be afforded a wide scope to determine how to discharge the duty.

cases.title: Affordable Medicines Trust and Others v Minister of Health and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Ngcobo J (Langa DCJ, Madala J, Mokgoro J , Moseneke J, O’Regan J, Sachs J, Skweyiya J, Van der Westhuizen J and Yacoob J)
cases.summary:
The applicants challenged: (i) section 22C(1)(a) of the Medicines and Related Substances Act 101 of 1965 to the extent that it authorised the Director-General of Health to issue medicine dispensing licences on prescribed conditions; and (ii) and regulations which regulated in further detail the licensing scheme under the Act.

Under the Act and the regulations, health care providers, such as medical practitioners and dentists, were not allowed to dispense (sell) medicines unless they had been issued with a licence by the Director-General of Health, and also had to do so from approved premises (locations).

Does license requiring a practitioner to practice from a specific approved premises infringe the constitutional right to freedom of movement enshrined in section 21 of the Constitution?

The Court ruled that the scheme for licensing which links licenses to particular premises does not infringe a medical professional’s section 21 right to freedom of movement; and instead is to be determined in terms of section 22 of the Constitution (freedom of trade, occupation and profession).

The Court recognised that the right to practise a profession (under section 22 of the Constitution) includes the right to decide where to practise the profession. However, the Court also reasoned that the requirement of a licence does not take away the right to choose where to practise medicine; it only requires that practices involving the compounding and dispensing of medicines must be run from license-linked premises.

The Court concluded that the constitutionality of the licensing scheme was not to be decided in terms of section 21 of the Constitution, but instead in terms of section 22 (freedom of trade, occupation and profession). Accordingly, the Court found that linking licensing for dispensing of medicine does not infringe the right to freedom of movement enshrined in section 21 of the Constitution.

cases.title: S v Jordan and Others (Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Task Force and Others as Amici Curiae)
cases.justicesConcurring:
Ngcobo J ( Chaskalson CJ, Kriegler J, Madala J, Du Plessis AJ and Skweyiya AJ)
O’Regan J and Sachs J (Langa DCJ, Ackermann J and Goldstone J) (dissent)
cases.summary:
The case concerned the constitutionality of the criminalisation of: (a) prostitution (carnal intercourse for reward); and (b) the keeping or managing of brothel. Both acts or activities were offences in terms of the Sexual Offences Act 23 of 1957 at the time.

[Note: This case was decided under the Interim Constitution, but the decision remains relevant. Section 26 of the Interim Constitution (the right to economic activity) corresponds with section 22 of the 1996 Constitution (the right in to freedom of trade, occupation and profession).]

The Sexual Offences Act 23 of 1957 criminalised owning or managing a brothel, as well as prostitution (carnal sexual intercourse for reward). These provisions were challenged under the Interim Constitution and it was argued that they violate.

The Court unanimously decided that the criminalisation of owning and managing brothels was constitutional; but split on the question of whether the criminalisation of prostitution was constitutional – the majority found that it was and the minority found that it was not. The result: both provisions were upheld as constitutional.

The Court unanimously agreed that criminalisation of prostitution does not infringe the rights to human dignity and economic activity, and that any limitation on privacy caused by the criminalisation of prostitution was reasonable justifiable.

The majority and minority ultimately ruled that the limitation of the right to economic activity by the criminalisation of prostitution was justifiable in an open and democratic society based on freedom and equality, taking into account:

(a) That the criminalisation of prostitution was in line with section 26(2) of the Interim Constitution in that it was for the legitimate purpose of promoting the protection or improvement of the quality of life and human development;

(b) Parliament’s responsibility to address and combat social problems;

(c) That prostitution is associated with violence, drug abuse and child trafficking;

(d) That Parliament has a wide discretion in choosing how to combat social problems, including through creating crimes; and

(e) That the courts must give effect to legislative choices made by Parliament except where the choices are unconstitutional.

O’Regan J and Sachs J agreed that criminalisation of prostitution does not infringe the rights to human dignity and economic activity, and that any limitation on privacy is reasonable justifiable. However, the minority found that the criminalisation of prostitution reinforces sexual double standards and gender stereotypes by making patrons accomplices to the crime at most, and the prostitute the primary offender.

cases.title: Fuel Retailers Association of Southern Africa v Director-General: Environmental Management, Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Environment, Mpumalanga Province and Others.
cases.justicesConcurring:
Ncgobo J [Moseneke DCJ, Madala J, Mokgoro J, Navsa AJ, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Skweyiya J, and Van der Westhuizen J]

Sachs J [dissenting]
cases.summary:
The case involved an application for a filling station in White River, Mpumalanga. Inama Trust applied and was granted authorisation to construct a filling station by the Mpumalanga environmental authorities. The applicant in the proceedings, Fuel Retailers Association of Southern Africa, an organisation which represents the interests of fuel retailers, objected the construction of the filing station stating that it will have an adverse impact on the environment. The applicant further objected the granting of the application by Inama Trust arguing that the authorities did not consider the proposed developments social, environmental and economic impacts in light of section 24 of the Constitution.

The applicant requested the authorisation of the construction of the filling station be set aside by the court and consideration of the social, economic and eviromental impacts of the proposed project be considered in light of section 24 of the Constitution.

The court considered whether the enviromental considerations were balanced with socio-economic considerations through the ideal of sustainable development. The court held that the National Enviromental Management Act of 1998 was enacted to give effect to section 24 of the Constitution, and that the act embraces the concept of sustainable development and requires people and their needs to be placed at the forefront of environmental management. The test to be applied in the cirsumstances is to assess, evaluate and consider whether the social, economic and environmental impact of the proposed development of the filling station was appropriately applied when the decision was taken to grant the application. Additionally, the test also requires that decisions must take into account the interests, needs and values of all interested and affected persons.

The court held that the socio-economic development and the protection of the environment are interlinked. Therefore in this case the establishment of filling stations in close proximity to one another may increase the pre-existing risk of adverse impact on the environment. The risk of contamination of underground water, soil, visual intrusion and light. An additional filling station may significantly increase this risk and increase environmental stress. The filling station may also affect the sustainability of existing filling stations with consequences for the job security of the employees of those filling stations. The court held that the enviromental authorities did not consider the impact of the increasing number of filling stations and of proposed filling station on existing ones. The court set aside the decision by the enviromental authorities stating that the authorities misconstrued the nature of their obligations and as a consequence failed to comply with a compulsory and material condition prescribed by the law for granting authorisation to establish a filling station.

The court held that section 24 of the Constitution recognises the interrelationship between the protection of the environment and socio-economic development. It contemplates the integration of environmental protection and socio-economic development and envisages that the two will be balanced through the ideal of sustainable development. The obligation of the environmental authorities to consider socio-economic factors includes the obligation to consider the impact of the increasing number of filling stations and of proposed filling station on existing ones. This obligation is wider than the requirement to assess need and desirability. Court held that the authorities misconstrued the nature of their obligations and as a consequence failed to comply with a compulsory and material condition prescribed by the law for granting authorisation to establish a filling station. The court set aside the decision of the environmental authorities granting authorisation to construct the proposed filling station and ordered the environmental authorities to reconsider the application by Inama Trust in the light of the judgment.

Sachs J dissenting judgement held that evidence does not indicate that opening a new filling station would pose or suggest any undue threat to the environment. That the question of sustainable development does not arise because this case does not require a decision on whether on balance the gains made in socio-economic development by opening up a new enterprise could appropriately permit a certain degree of negative impact on the environment. This matter was focused on the risk of overtrading and profits of existing petrol stations. This case is a question of the economic factor that should have been taken into account when the question of sustainable development was being considered. However, the question of possible overtrading is not one which decision-makers in this matter were called upon to consider. Therefore, the dissenting judgement held that the decision to set aside the determination of the decision-makers was not supported.

cases.title: MEC: Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Environment and Another v HTF Developers (Pty) Limited
cases.justicesConcurring:
Skweyiya J [ Moseneke DCJ, Sachs J and Van der Westhuizen J ]
Ngcobo J [ seperate concurring]
cases.summary:
The respondent HTF developers owns property which, with the approval of the relevant housing authority, planned to sub-divide into residential stands for sale to individual buyers. On 18 July 2005, the second applicant sent a letter to the respondent identifying the property under development as “virgin ground”. The cultivation or use of virgin ground was considered to have a substantial detrimental effect on the environment in terms of section 21(1) of the Environmental Conservation Act of 1989 (ECA) and therefore prohibited in terms of section 22 of the ECA unless written authorisation was granted. The respondent argued that the land in question did not fall within the definition of “virgin land” and therefore the construction activities were not subject to the authorisation in terms of the act. Accordingly, the respondent insisted that the first applicant did not have the legal basis for directing that development of the property must stop.

The case is concerned primarily with the interaction of two sections in the Environment Conservation Act of 1989 ( ECA), which allowed the applicant, the provincial Department for Agriculture, Conservation & Environment in Gauteng to prevent the development of a housing estate as a result of the applicants understanding that the development threatened the existence of certain Red Data species and naturally existing corridors that are formed by naturally formed geological ridges in Gauteng. Section 31A of the ECA empowers a named authority to direct any person who performs or fails to perform an activity that is causing or may cause damage to the environment, to stop the harmful activity or take remedial steps within a specified period. Section 32 of the ECA provides that a 30-day notice and comment procedure must be followed before directions are issued in terms of the ECA.

The central issue was whether the section 32 notice and comment procedure was required when direction are issued to a specific person or entity and not to general members of the public thereby requiring a draft notice published for comment in the Government Gazette. It was held that the notice and comment procedure is not applicable but that directions issued in terms of s31 are subject to procedural fairness requirements. The court held that Section 31A must be interpreted in a manner that is consistent with the overall framework of the ECA. That Section 31A cannot be subject to the rigid procedural requirements of Section 32 because this would hamper the ability of officials to respond appropriately to harmful situations.

The court held that in interpreting the relevant sections of the ECA, the test is to use the constitutional right to environmental considerations of section 24 and the principles articulated by the National Environmental Management Act of 1998 (NEMA), in particular the need to achieve socially, environmentally and economically sustainable development.

The court held that the observance of the 30-day notice and comment procedure is appropriate for directions generally applicable to members of the public, and not to directions applicable to a specific person or entity. Directions issued in term of section 31A are, however, subject to procedural fairness requirements in the form of section 36 of the ECA and administrative review under the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act of 2000. Further, the urgency of the situation may dictate the extent of the procedural fairness imposed on the administrator. This interpretation allows for sufficient procedural flexibility, which is necessary for organs of state to react to potential or actual environmental damage in a range of different time frames. The court held that the exercise of power in terms of section 31A of the ECA should not be constrained by the procedural requirements of section 32 of the same Act.

Ngcobo J separate concurring judgement emphasised that the obligations on authorities to adopt a risk averse and cautious approach and to remedy negative impacts on the environment. Even though the provisions of section 32 do not apply to the exercise of powers in section 31A, a person affected by the direction would still have the opportunity to make representations consistent with procedural fairness.

cases.title: First National Bank of SA Limited t/a Wesbank v Commissioner for the South African Revenue Services and Another; First National Bank of SA Limited t/a Wesbank v Minister of Finance
cases.justicesConcurring: Ackermann J [Chaskalson CJ, Langa DCJ, Kriegler J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, Sachs J, Yacoob J, Du Plessis AJ and Skweyiya AJ]
cases.summary:
FNB challenged the constitutionality of section 114 of the Customs and Excise Act 91 of 1964 .

Section 114 allowed the SARS Commissioner to seize and sell: (i) property in the possession of a debtor (person/entity who/which owes money) to satisfy certain debts owed to SARS (this meant that even property owned by a different person/entity and not owned by debtor, but merely in the debtor’s possession, could be seized and sold); and (ii) the property without authorisation by a court.

FNB owned and had leased cars to two different debtors who owed SARS debts; SARS seized the cars which were in the possession of the debtors in terms of section 114.

The Court was faced with the question of whether section 114 infringed section 25 of the Constitution (right to property) by allowing SARS to seize property (owned by a third party) from a debtor in order to satisfy the debts of the debtor (not the debts of the third party (owner)).

The Court ruled that the effect of the section deprived FNB permanently of all its rights and benefits as owner of the vehicles. On applying the test for whether the deprivation was arbitrary or not, and therefore whether the deprivation was constitutional or not, the Court concluded that the deprivation (the seizure by SARS under section 114 of FNB’s vehicles) was arbitrary and unconstitutional because there was insufficient reason justifying it: (i) There was no connection between the debt of the debtors and the owner of the property (FNB); (ii) There was no connection between the debt and the property (FNB’s vehicles); (iii) The property owner (FNB) did not detriment SARS by placing the property (the vehicles) in the possession of the debtor (hence no reason why the property owner should be subjected to interference or sanction).

(i) Section 25 mainly enshrines a negative protection of property (meaning that it protects or prevents existing property rights or property rights which come into existence from interference or intrusion), and does not enshrine the right to gain property rights.

(ii) The Court indicated that one of the types of property included under section 25, in addition to land (see section 25(4)(b)), is ‘tangible moveables’ (physical, moveable things e.g. motor vehicles).

(iii) ‘Deprivation’ is a wider term than and would include ‘expropriation[s]’ as contained in section 25: ‘deprivation’ refers to interference with (limitation on) the use or enjoyment of private property; whereas ‘expropriation’ means ‘confiscation’, ‘taking’ or ‘dispossession’ of the right or the property. (To determine whether deprivation is also an expropriation, the purpose of the law or conduct is assessed. If the purpose is to confiscate then the law or act expropriates. Where taking possession or seizing is merely ‘incidental’ (merely connected) to a different legitimate objective then the taking or seizing will not be an expropriation but a deprivation.)

(iv) If deprivation only interferes (limits) in the right to property, then it must be arbitrary, and must reasonable and justifiable in terms of section 36(1) of the Constitution, in order to be constitutional. If the deprivation is also an expropriation, then it must be justifiable in terms of section 25(2)(a) in order to be constitutional.

(v) A deprivation (limitation) is ‘arbitrary’ and unconstitutional when there is not ‘sufficient reason’ for it, or it is procedurally unfair. A list of factors is taken into account to determine whether there is ‘sufficient reason’, including: the nature and complexity of the relationship between the means and ends; and the nature or type of the right or property in question (i.e. ownership in land or other extensive property rights will require more justification in order to be sufficient).

cases.title: Government of the Republic of South Africa and Others v Grootboom and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Yacoob J [  Chaskalson P, Langa DP, Goldstone J, Kriegler J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, Ngcobo J, O’Regan J, Sachs J and Cameron AJ ]
cases.summary:
The respondents were 510 children and 390 adults who were living in appalling circumstances in Wallacedene informal settlement. Many had applied for subsidized low-cost housing through the municipality and had been on the waiting list for a period of up to seven years. While waiting to be allocated housing, they decided to move and illegally live on someones private land. Respondents were then evicted from these informal homes.Respondents applied to the High Court seeking an order requiring the government to provide them with adequate basic shelter or housing until they obtained permanent accommodation and certain relief. Respondents stated that sections 26 and 28 of the Constitution of South Africa guaranteed the right of everyone to access to adequate housing and the right of children to be afforded special protection, and, in particular, shelter. The appellants were ordered to provide the respondents with tents, portable latrines and a regular supply of water by way of minimal shelter. This decision formed the basis for the appeal to the Constitutional Court.

The court considered whether the measures taken by the state to realise the rights afforded by s26 of the consititution were reasonable. Whether the City of Cape Town’s housing programmes met the obligations imposed on them by section 26. The court found the right to access to adequate housing could not be seen in isolation; it had to be interpreted in the light of its close relationship with the other socio-economic rights.

The court held that the state was obliged to take positive action to meet the needs of those living in extreme conditions of poverty, homelessness or intolerable housing. In this case the determination of a minimum obligation in the context of the right to have access to adequate housing presented difficult questions, because the needs of the respondents were so diverse. The court held that the state therefore had to create the conditions for access to adequate housing for people at all economic levels of society. The extent of the state's obligation was defined by three key elements, which had to be considered separately: the obligation to take reasonable legislative and other measures, to achieve the progressive realisation of s26, and within available resources. For a person to have access to adequate housing, the court held, there had to be the provision of land, services (such as the provision of water, the removal of sewage and the financing of all these) and a dwelling.

The court further held that section 26 placed a obligation on the state and all other entities and persons to desist from preventing or impairing the right of access to adequate housing. The manner in which the eviction in this case had been carried out had resulted in a breach of this obligation.

A reasonable housing program, capable of facilitating the realisation of the right, had clearly to allocate responsibilities and tasks to the different spheres of government and ensure that the appropriate financial and human resources were available to implement it. The formation of a program, however, was only the first stage in meeting the state's obligations. The program also had to be reasonably implemented, as failure to do so would not constitute compliance with the state's obligations. The court therefore issued a declaratory order which required the state to devise and implement a programme that included measures to provide relief.

The Court first examined what the precise obligations of the government are under section 26 of the Constitution. In doing so, the Court stated that section 26 must be interpreted in light of the remainder of the Constitution and the historical and social circumstances in which it is set. Section 26 requires that the state take reasonable legislative and other measures within the context of available resources to ensure access to adequate housing. The Court determined that the nationwide housing programme falls short of constitutional obligations insofar as it fails to provide relief for those in desperate need of housing.

Further, the court confirmed that the Constitution does not draw a distinction between housing, on one hand, and shelter on another. And so it concluded that that neither section 26 nor section 28 of the Constitution can be read to entitle respondents to claim shelter immediately upon demand. The Court then examined whether the respondents were entitled to broaden the scope of the original application so that persons without children would be equally entitled to shelter. To this the Court stated that under section 26(2) of the Constitution, the government is required to devise and implement, within its available resources, a comprehensive and coordinated program progressively to realize the right of access to adequate housing. This right extends to all individuals including those without children.

Therefore the Constitutional Court declared that the government had not met its constitutional obligations and ordered the government, within its available resources, to devise, fund, implement and supervise measures to provide relief for all, including those without children, who are in desperate need.

cases.title: City of Johannesburg Metropolitan Municipality v Blue Moonlight Properties
cases.justicesConcurring: Van der Westhuizen J [  Moseneke DCJ, Cameron J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Mogoeng J, Nkabinde J, Skweyiya J, Yacoob J ]
cases.summary:
This case concerns the conflict between the constitutional right to adequate housing and an owner’s right to develop private property. Eighty-six poor individuals were unlawfully occupying private unused industrial facilities as living quarters. The owner of the property (Blue Moonlight) sued to evict the occupiers in order to develop the property, which would almost certainly render them homeless. The occupiers argued that the city had an obligation to provide them with temporary housing under the Constitution and the Prevention of Illegal Eviction and Unlawful Occupation of Land Act, 19 of 1998 (PIE Act) before they could be evicted.

The court considered whether the 86 occupiers must be evicted to allow the owner to fully exercise its rights regarding its property and, if so, whether their eviction must be linked to an order that the City provide them with accommodation. The applicant’s position is that it is neither obliged nor able to provide accommodation in these circumstances. The owner wishes to exercise its right to develop its property and wants no part in the dispute about the City‘s responsibilities or the plight of the occupiers. The court held that a court cannot grant an eviction order pursuant to the PIE Act unless it is just and equitable to do so. In deciding whether an eviction is just and equitable, the court considered that many of the occupiers had lived on the property for a very long time, the occupation had once been lawful, Blue Moonlight was aware of the occupiers’ presence when it purchased the property, and the eviction of the occupiers would render them homeless while there was no competing risk of homelessness on the part of Blue Moonlight. The Court found that eviction would not be just or equitable until the city could provide the occupiers with alternate housing. The court stated that in circumstances where an eviction of occupiers from private property would render the occupiers homeless, the rights of the property owners may have to temporarily yield to the occupiers’ right to housing.

The Court therefore ordered the city to provide the occupiers with adequate alternate housing. In so doing, the Court rejected the city’s contention that the city did not have adequate financial resources with which to provide alternate housing. Finally, the Court insisted that there be a link between the date of eviction and the date by which the city would have to provide such housing to ensure that the occupiers were not rendered homeless by the eviction.

The court held that an owner's constitutional right not to be deprived of property, must be interpreted in a social and historical context and be balanced against the right of access to adequate housing and not to be evicted arbitrarily from one's home. In this case even though housing unlawful occupiers indefinitely suspends an owner's right to use and enjoy property, evictions can only be carried out in terms of the PIE act, and are only permissible where just and equitable.

Whether it was just and equitable to order eviction under PIE act depended on whether the City had made reasonable efforts to provide alternative accommodation to the occupiers. The Court held that the City unreasonably and thus unconstitutionally breached the occupiers’ right of access to adequate housing under s 26 of the Constitution by not providing them with temporary accommodation, in circumstances in which their imminent eviction would render them homeless.

The City’s claim that it lacked the resources to do so was rejected. The court therefore held that the occupiers had to vacate the properties by a given date, but stipulated that the City was to provide the evictees with "temporary accommodation in a location as near as feasibly possible to the area" in which the building was situated.

The court emphasised that this case concerns temporary as defined in Chapter 12 and not permanent housing. The obligation, while derived from the right to progressive realisation of adequate housing in terms of section 26(2) of the Constitution, is distinct from the obligation to address permanent housing needs.

cases.title: Minister of Health and Others v Treatment Action Campaign and Others (No 2)
cases.justicesConcurring: Chief Justice Chaskalson A ; Deputy Chief Justice Langa PN; Justice Ackermann L; Justice Goldstone RJ; Acting Justice Du Plessis B; Justice Kriegler JC;  Justice Madala T; Justice Ngcobo S; Justice O’ Reagen K; Justice Sachs AL  and Acting Justice Skewyiya T
cases.summary:
The respondents in the Constitutional Court judgment concerned various civil society organisations and associations involved in the treatment of people with HIV/AIDS. The respondents launched a constitutional challenge in the North Gauteng High Court challenging the applicant’s programme for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV and provision of the anti-retroviral drug, Nevaripine at only certain limited research public healthcare facilities. The North Gauteng High Court made a structural interdict that obliged the State to extend the provision of Nevirapine to pregnant women with HIV beyond the limited public research facilities and to provide a comprehensive plan to prevent or reduce the prevention of HIV transmission from mother to child. The judgment was appealed by the applicants and the Constitutional Court specifically considered the applicants’ policy in light of its constitutional obligations in terms of sections 27(1)(a) and (2) of the Constitution.The Constitutional Court held that the applicants failed to fulfil their constitutional duty in this regard.

This Constitutional Court judgment is critical in understanding the obligations resting on the State in terms of section 27(2) of the Constitution in fulfilling access to a socio-economic right, in this regard specifically the constitutional right to access healthcare services. Sections 27(1)(a)) of the Constitution provides that everyone has the right to have access to health care services, that includes reproductive healthcare. The right however is not an absolute right against the State. The State must show it took “reasonable legislative and other measures, within its available resources” to make the right available.

The Constitutional Court essentially focused on two issues.
