Firstly, the reasonability of the applicant’s policy that restricted the provision of the anti-retroviral drug, Nevirapine to pregnant women at only certain public healthcare training and research facilities. Secondly, the reasonability of the State’s failure develop a comprehensive programme to combat mother-to-child transmission of HIV in light of the State’s obligations in terms of sections 27(1)(a) and (2) of the Constitution.

A key aspect that stood out in analysing the reasonability of the applicants’ policy restricting the provision of Nevaripine, was the applicants’ failure to take into account pregnant HIV mothers and their new-born children who do not have access to these public research sites. No provision was made for these extremely vulernable group of women.

The North Gauteng High Court’s structural interdict was set aside by the Constitutional Court and the Constitutional Court made various detailed orders including removing the present restrictions on the administration of Nevirapine without delay. The Constitutional Court also confirmed that the applicants have a constitutional duty to devise a comprehensive plan to ensure pregnant women and their new-born babies have access to healthcare services to combat mother-to child transmission of HIV.

On considering the obligations of sections 27(1)(a) and (2) of the Constitution on the applicants, the Constitutional Court recognised that the Executive has the prerogative to make policy. However, the Court has a duty to determine whether these measures adopted are reasonable. In this regard the Constitutional Court relied strongly on the Constitutional Court judgment of Government of the Republic of South Africa and Others v Grootboom and Other that held : “to be reasonable, measures cannot leave out of account the degree and extent of the denial of the right they endeavour to realise. Those whose needs are the most urgent and whose ability to enjoy all rights therefore is most in peril, must not be ignored by the measures aimed at achieving realisation of the right”.

Although the Constitutional Court appreciated the applicants’ argument that the research and training sites would provide further ongoing data to establish the best prevention programme, the Court emphasised that there was no safety concerns about the drug and that the applicants’ policy was not reasonable considering the exclusion vulnerable HIV pregnant women who do not have access to these specific sites.

cases.title: Soobramoney v Minister of Health (Kwazulu-Natal)
cases.justicesConcurring: Chaskalson P, Langa DP, Ackermann J, Didcott J, Goldstone J, Kriegler J,  Madala J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, Sachs J
cases.summary:
The appellant in this matter was a 41-year-old unemployed man who suffered from chronic renal failure. He required dialysis two to three times a week. Due to his financial circumstances he applied to a provincial State Hospital to receive the treatment. The Addington State Hospital however only had 20 dialysis machines available and because of the limited resources had a strict policy regarding access to renal dialysis and only patients that suffered from acute renal failure and were eligible for a kidney transplant were given access. Due to the nature of his illness, the appellant was denied treatment and he applied to the Durban High Court for an order directing Addington Hospital to provide him with ongoing dialysis and treatment and interdicting the Hospital from refusing him admission to the renal unit. The Durban High Court dismissed the application and the appellant urgently applied to the Constitutional Court to hear the matter.

The Constitutional Court had to decide whether the appellant, who suffered from chronic renal failure, had a right to receive ongoing renal dialysis from a State Hospital in terms of section 27 and more specifically section 27(3) of the Constitution which provides that “No one may be refused emergency medical treatment”. Due to a shortage of resources the provincial hospital had a strict policy regarding access to renal dialysis and only patients that suffered from acute renal failure and were eligible for a kidney transplant would be given dialysis treatment. The appellant was denied treatment and made an urgent application the Durban High Court for an order that the hospital be obliged to provide him treatment and held that the State had in obligation in terms of section 27(3) and section 10 of the Constitution. The application was dismissed and the appellant directly applied to the Constitutional Court.

Chaskalson P, held that the kind of treatment the appellant requires would need to be provided to all patients in similar conditions and State resources could not accommodate this demand. The costs associated with extending renal dialysis to all patients in similar conditions would not be reasonable and the State would not be able to meet all its other constitutional obligations. Furthermore, Chaskalson P emphasised that the right not be refused emergency medical treatment relates to the right to receive immediate medical attention and not to be turned away from a hospital which is able to provide the necessary treatment. The appellant needed renal dialysis two to three times a week and this did not constitute an emergency in terms of section 27(3) of the Constitution. The Constitutional Court therefore dismissed the appeal and held that there was no breach of the constitutional obligation resting on the State in this matter.

This judgment provided clarity regarding the constitutional obligation resting on the State to provide everyone access to healthcare services in terms of section 27 of the Constitution and more specifically the obligation relating to section 27(3) of the Constitution. Section 27(3) of the Constitution provides that “No one may be refused emergency medical treatment”. Chaskalson P writing for the majority emphasised that the right not to be refused emergency medical treatment essentially means that a person may not be refused immediate medical attention when they are experiencing a sudden medical emergency and cannot be denied ambulance services or be turned away from a hospital. In this matter the applicant suffered from a chronic renal failure and required dialysis treatment. The Constitutional Court held that this does not relate to an emergency calling for immediate remedial treatment. It is also critical to note that the Constitutional Court that the right not to be refused emergency medical treatment is independent from the right to life in section 11 of the Constitution.

cases.title: Teddy Bear Clinic for Abused Children and Another v Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Khampepe J, Mogoeng CJ, Bosielo AJ, Froneman J, Jafta J, Mhlantla AJ, Nkabinde J, Skweyiya J and Zondo J
cases.summary:
The applicants, in the High Court, filed an application to challenge ss 15 and 16 of the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Act. They argued it was unconstitutional to the extent that it criminalized consensual sexual conduct between children. The North Guateng High Court declared the relevant sections unconstitutional and therefore invalid. An application for confirmation of invalidity was launched before the Constitutional Court.

In a unanimous judgment, the Constitutional Court found that sections 15 and 16 of the Act were unconstitutional in that they infringed the rights of adolescents (12- to 16-year olds) to dignity and privacy, and further in that they violated the best-interests principle contained in section 28(2) of the Constitution. Relying on expert evidence, the Court concluded that the provisions criminalized what constituted developmentally normal conduct for adolescents, and adversely affected the very children the Act sought to protect. The effects of the provisions were found not to be rationally related to the State’s purpose of protecting children.

The provisions were declared invalid only to the extent that they criminalized consensual sexual conduct between adolescents.

The Constitutional Court suspended the declaration of invalidity for 18 months to allow Parliament to amend the provisions. Khampepe J further ordered a suspension on all investigations, arrests, prosecutions and criminal and ancillary proceedings (regarding adolescents) in relation to sections 15 and 16 of the Act, until Parliament has remedied the defects identified. Finally, the Minister was ordered to take the necessary steps to ensure that the details of any adolescent convicted of an offence in terms of sections 15 or 16 of the Act will not appear in the National Register for Sex Offenders and that such an adolescent will have his or her criminal record removed.

The court held that in respect of whether the criminalization of consensual sexual conduct between children violated section 28 of the Constitution, it was necessary to firstly give content to section 28.

The court observed that section 28 is both a self-standing right and a guiding principle in respect of all matters affecting the child. What is in the best interests of the child in each case will require a consideration of various factors. Further, it is not necessary that the specific interests of the child in the case before the court are affected, but rather whether the interests of children in general are affected. Legislation would be inconsistent with this right if it is demonstrated to be against the interests of children in general.

In the present case, it was clear for the court that the interests of children were adversely affected for several reasons. Most importantly, it ran the risk of exposing children to the harmful effects of the criminal justice system and could undermine support structures by deterring adolescents from seeking help and could create a breakdown in parental care.

cases.title: Head of Department : Mpumalanga Department of Education and Another v Hoërskool Ermelo and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Moseneke DCJ CJ (Langa CJ, Cameron J, Mokgoro J, Ngcobo J, Nkabinde J, O’Regan J, Sachs J, Skweyiya J and Van der Westhuizen J)
cases.summary:
Hoërskool Ermelo’s language policy set teaching at the school in Afrikaans only, effectively preventing non-Afrikaans speaking learners from being enrolled at the school (despite Hoërskool Ermelo having (physical) space to accommodate more learners). At the time, the English medium schools in Ermelo were full, creating a shortage of English medium schooling capacity. Given the need to accommodate non-Afrikaans learners, the Head of Department: Mpumalanga Department of the Education (HoD) requested Hoërskool Ermelo’s Governing Body to amend its language policy to provide for teaching in both Afrikaans and English. The Governing Body refused. The HoD then withdrew the Governing Body’s function to determine the school’s language policy. Through the appointment of an interim committee, the HoD caused Hoërskool Ermelo’s language policy to be amended to provide for teaching in both Afrikaans and English, thereby allowing the enrolment of the excess non-Afrikaans speaking learners at Hoërskool Ermelo and for them to be taught in English under the adjusted policy.

The case concerned the constitutional right to be taught in an official language of one’s choice (section 29(2) of the Constitution) and the power of the Head of Department of Education (HoD) to withdraw the function of a school governing body to determine the school’s language policy (section 22 of the Schools Act 84 of 1996).

English medium schools in the region of Ermelo were full, whilst Hoërskool Ermelo had the physical capacity to accommodate more learners. Following Hoërskool Ermelo’s Governing Body refusal to amend its language policy to provide for teaching in both Afrikaans and English in order to accommodate non-Afrikaans speaking learners in need, the HoD withdrew the Governing Body’s function to determine the school’s language policy. Through the appointment of an interim committee, the HoD caused Hoërskool Ermelo’s language policy to be amended to provide for teaching in both Afrikaans and English, thereby allowing the enrolment of the non-Afrikaans speaking learners.

The Court noted that there is a great need to ensure that the constitutional rights to education and to be taught in an official language of one’s choice are properly protected, and that Court observed that the government may intervene to protect these constitutional rights where School Governing Body positions are unreasonable and at odds with the rights.

However, the Court found that (technically) the HoD’s decisions to withdraw the Governing Body’s function (to determine the school language policy) and appoint the interim committee were invalid because decisions were taken contrary to the pre-requisites and procedural fairness requirements for the taking of such decisions under the Schools Act.

The Court ruled that whilst the state (under the Schools Act) grants the authority to School Governing Bodies (SGBs) to determine the language policies of public schools, the state continues to carry obligations under section 29(2) of the Constitution, namely the obligation to ensure effective access to teaching in the language of choice. SBGs are entrusted with a public resource (the school and its assets) which must be managed not only in the interests of current learners, but also in the interests of the community and in the light of the values of our Constitution. Measures taken by SGBs and the state must be aligned to what is reasonably achievable and responsive to the need for historical redress.

In order for the state to fulfil its obligations under section 29(2) of the Constitution, it must be able to intervene where SGBs exercise their power unreasonably and at odds with the constitutional promises to receive basic education and for learners to be taught in a language of their choice.

cases.title: Independent Institute of Education (Pty) Limited v Kwazulu-Natal Law Society and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ, Froneman J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Madlanga J, Mathopo AJ, Mhlantla J, Theron J, and Victor AJ
cases.summary:
The applicant was accredited to offer and confer an LLB degree on its graduates. However, the KwaZulu-Natal Law Society took the position that it would not register articles of clerkship of aspirant attorneys with degrees from such institutions. The reason for this decision was because it read section 26(1)(a) of the Legal Practice Act, which lays out the requirements for someone to qualify as an admitted legal practictioner, as excluding the applicant from its purview in terms of where a person may obtain an LLB from in order to qualify.

The applicant then applied to the High Court to have s26(1)(a) declared unconstitutional. The High Court found in favour of the applicant and declared the section unconstitutional and therefore invalid. An application was then filed before the Constitutional Court to have the order of invalidity confirmed.

The court held that the words “any university” in section 26(1)(a) of the Legal Practice Act are capable of, and should be, given a meaning that is consistent with the provisions of section 29(3) of the Constitution, and which gives effect to section 39(2). The court held that the fact that the KwaZulu-Natal Law Society sought to interpret a word in one piece of legislation through the lens of a special meaning given to it in another legislation is impermissible in law save for exceptional circumstances. Therefore, “any university” should be given its ordinary meaning, which would include private institutions such as the applicant. For these reasons, the court did not confirm the order the invalidity.

A second judgment penned by Theron J and concurred in by Froneman J concurred with the first judgment in that the term “university” in section 26(1)(a) of the LPA is reasonably capable of a constitutionally-compliant interpretation and accordingly that the High Court’s declaration of constitutional invalidity should be set aside. The second judgment addressed the narrow principle that courts should interpret legislative provisions with reference to, and consistently with, other legislation.

The court held that when interpreting legislation, section 39(2) of the Constitution requires courts to promote the Bill of Rights. In this regard, section 29 clearly provides for private institutions of education, of which the applicant falls under. The establishment of a constitutionally-compliant institution like the applicant promotes the values embedded in section 29. It ensures access to higher education. Therefore, for the court, this only adds to the conclusion that an independent higher education institute like the applicant should be considered a ”university” in terms of s26(1) of the Legal Practice Act. Liesching v The State [2016] ZACC 41; 2017 (2) SACR 193 (CC); 2017 (4) BCLR 454 (CC) at para 33 (Liesching I). Liesching I confirms Canca v Mount Frere Municipality 1984 (2) SA 830 (Tks).

cases.title: My Vote Counts NPC v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Khampepe J, Madlanga J, Nkabinde J, Theron AJ, Mogoeng CJ, Molemela AJ, Tshiqi AJ, Cameron J, Moseneke DCJ, Froneman J and Jappie AJ
cases.summary:
The applicant brought an application to compel Parliament to pass legislation that would oblige political parties to disclose the source of their private funding. The applicant argued that information about the private funding of political parties was important to citizens making an informed decision when voting. The applicant brought an application to compel Parliament to pass legislation that would oblige political parties to disclose the source of their private funding. The applicant argued that information about the private funding of political parties was important to citizens making an informed decision when voting.

The question before the court was that since PAIA does not require disclosure of political funding, could this court grant an order compelling Parliament to enact legislation that would make the disclosure of private funding compulsory. The court dismissed the applicant’s claim because the applicant had failed to attack the constitutionality of PAIA as the legislation giving effect to section 32. The applicant could not rely directly on section 32 as there was legislation that was meant to give effect to right.

PAIA was the national legislation giving effect to section 32. The fact that PAIA may have shortcomings in the protection of section 32 does not mean that it is not the legislation that was enacted to give effect to section 32. There are other prices of legislation that give effect to section 32 but they can be distinguished from PAIA because the main aim of these other pieces of legislation is not the right of access to information.

The majority judgement written by Khampepe J, Madlanga J, Nkabinde J and Theron AJ (Mogoeng CJ, Molemela AJ and Tshiqi AJ concurring) found that the Promotion of Access to Information Act (PAIA) was the legislation enacted to give effect to section 32, the right to access to information. The applicant should therefore have attacked the constitutional validity of PAIA.

The minority judgement written by Cameron J (Moseneke DCJ, Froneman J and Jappie AJ concurring) found that the right to access of information requires the regular and compulsory disclosure of sources of private funding of political parties. The minority judgement also agreed with the applicant that private funding disclosure by political parties was important to the exercise and protection of the right to vote. The minority judgement disagreed with the majority judgement’s finding that the applicant should have challenged PAIA because it is not the only legislation that should give effect to the right of access to information.

cases.title: My Vote Counts NPC v Minister of Justice and Correctional Services and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ, Zondo DCJ, Dlodlo AJ, Goliath AJ, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Madlanga J, Petse AJ, Theron J, Froneman J and Cachalia AJ.
cases.summary:
The applicant challenged the constitutionality of the Promotion of Access to Information Act (PAIA). PAIA was enacted to give effect to section 32, the right of access to information but it failed to fully give effect to this particularly in respect of the funding of political parties and independent candidates.

The High Court found that PAIA does not apply to political parties or independent candidates and there are no records of their private funding. PAIA’s failure to provide access to information on private funding made in inconsistent with sections 32, 7(2), and 19 of the Constitution.

The applicant challenged the constitutionality of the Promotion of Access to Information Act (PAIA). PAIA was enacted to give effect to section 32, the right of access to information but it failed to fully give effect to this particularly in respect of the funding of political parties and independent candidates.

The High Court found that PAIA does not apply to political parties or independent candidates and there are no records of their private funding. PAIA’s failure to provide access to information on private funding made in inconsistent with sections 32, 7(2), and 19 of the Constitution.

The question was whether the High Court had been correct in its ruling of unconstitutionality of PAIA to the extent that it failed to provide for the disclosure of private funding.

The Court agreed with the High Court that PAIA was unconstitutional because it failed to provide for the disclosure of private funding of political parties and independent candidates. This was because there was a link between the right to vote and the right of access to information. Without access to information, citizens would not be able to make responsible political decisions. The obligation to record, preserve, and make private funding information easily accessible to the public means that it must be accessible to NGO’s, the media, and other political players. The court confirmed the order made by the High Court.

PAIA was the national legislation enacted to give effect to section 32. It had failed to give full effect to the right as intended by the Constitution because it failed to provide for the disclosure of private funding of political players. The word ”everyone” as provided for by the right encompasses political parties and independent candidates. When information is held by another person, it is only accessible when it is required. The person wanting the information must show that there is a legitimate reason for wanting the information. It would not make information accessible to the general public if they had to submit requests for the private funding of political parties. Information on the private funding of political parties needed to be accessible and the failure to do so rendered PAIA unconstitutional.

The majority judgement written by Mogoeng CJ (with Zondo DCJ, Dlodlo AJ, Goliath AJ, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Madlanga J, Petse AJ and Theron J concurring) agreed with the finding of the High Court that PAIA was unconstitutional in so far as it failed to provide information on the private funding of political parties and independent candidates.

cases.title: University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others v Minister of Justice and Correctional Services and Others; Association of Debt Recovery Agents NPC v University of Stellenbosch Legal   Aid Clinic and Others; Mavava Trading 279 (Pty) Ltd and Others v University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others
cases.justicesConcurring: Mogoeng CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Bosielo AJ, Cameron J, Froneman J, Jafta J, Khampepe J, Madlanga J, Mhlantla J, Nkabinde J and Zondo J
cases.summary:
The Stellenbosch Law Clinic’s clients all had emoluments attachment orders issued against them by clerks of the court employed in various Magistrates’ offices. They had approached a company known as SA Multiloan in Stellenbosch for small loans. Later when they fell into arrears, the creditor provider demanded that they sign further documents which resulted in default judgments and emoluments attachment orders obtained by the credit providers. This allowed for the deduction of the judgment debt from their salaries or wages.

As a result of this, all the applicants approached the Law Clinic to institute proceedings in the High Court to have s65(J) declared unconstitutional. Their argument was that s65(J) allowed for emoluments attachment orders to be obtained without judicial oversight. The High Court agreed with them and declared the section unconstitutional and therefore invalid.

Application was then filed to the Constitutional Court to confirm invalidity of s65(J). The majority judgment, written by Cameron J, disagreed with Jafta J’s conclusion that it was possible to interpret s65J as providing for judicial oversight. S65J(2) licenses the issuing of an emoluments attachment order where the debtor consents in writing; or if “the court has so authorised”. The conjunction “or” seems to make plain that an emoluments attachment order may be obtained through the debtor’s written consent even when the court has not authorised it.

Additionally, s65J(1) posits that a judgment creditor, not a court, causes an emoluments attachment order to be issued from a court. And once issued, s65J(5) provides that the order may be executed “as if it were a court judgment”. This wording allows for execution without judicial oversight. The majority judgment therefore concluded that the plain language of the provision shows it permitted judicially unsanctioned enforcement of judgment debts. Therefore, the section was unconstitutional.

Zondo J concurred with the majority judgment but wrote separately. He took the view that in order for s65J(1)(a) to be read to mean that it is the court that issues emoluments attachment orders, one would have to read the phrase “issued from the court” to mean “issued by the court”. Zondo J held that there is no room for this interpretation.

The remedy adopted by Zondo J was supported by the majority. It was one of a combination of reading-in and severance and not the remedy adopted by the High Court. Accordingly, Zondo J did not confirm the order of constitutional invalidity made by the High Court, but rather ordered the reading-in, and severance of, certain words in section 65J(2)(a) and (b) in order to remedy the constitutional defect.

Jafta J held that the High Court erred in proceeding from the premise that s65J(2) did not provide for judicial oversight without interpreting that section. He held that the Court was bound to determine for itself whether indeed the section failed to provide for judicial oversight.

Jafta J held further that it should be determined whether the words “from the court” are capable of a meaning that accords with the assumed constitutional guarantee that, whenever execution is sought against one’s property – regardless of whether movable or immovable – the execution must be subject to judicial oversight.

Jafta J held that s65J indeed provides for judicial supervision. Therefore, assuming that the Constitution requires judicial supervision when emoluments attachment orders are issued, the section meets the requirement. Jafta J added that in these circumstances he cannot confirm the order of invalidity made by the High Court.

The majority held that a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any form of property occurs without judicial oversight of a court.

cases.title: AB and Another v Minister of Social Development
cases.justicesConcurring:
Nkabinde J [ Mogoeng CJ, Moseneke DCJ, Bosielo AJ, Jafta J, Mhlantla J and Zondo J] [majority]

Khampepe J [ Cameron J, Froneman J and Madlanga J concurring ] [ minority]

cases.title: Fose v Minister of Safety and Security
cases.justicesConcurring:
Ackermann J [Chaskalson P, Mahomed DP, Langa J, Madala J, Mokgoro J and Sachs J O'Regan J] [majority]

Didcott J and Kriegler J [separate concurring]
cases.summary:
The applicant stated that members of the South African Police Services violated his fundamental rights by widespread and persistent form of abuses including series of assaults and torture over a two day period. The applicant sued the Minister of Safety and Security for damages for pain and suffering, insult, shock, past and future medical expenses and loss of enjoyment of the amenities of life. He further sued for constitutional damages for the infringement of his constitutional right not to be tortured and not to be subject to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment and for infringements to his rights to dignity and privacy.

In this case the court considered whether to award damages/money to the applicant if there was a finding of wrongdoing by the government and violation of constitutional rights. Section 38 of the Constitution empowers a court to award “appropriate relief”, including a declaration of rights, where a right in the Bill of Rights has been violated. The applicant in this case successfully proved that he was assaulted by members of the police therefore he would be awarded substantial compensatory damages for pain and suffering, insult, shock, past and future medical expenses and loss of enjoyment of the amenities of life. The court then had to consider whether in addition to this award, the applicant should receive damages that are punitive in nature. That is, whether the court should award damages to the applicant which aim to punish or deter government from future similar acts.

The court held that this question is answered on a case by case basis and when determining the answer to this question courts must look at the following; what relief will best ensure protection and enforcement of the constitutional rights and where necessary innovative remedies can apply, the relief must vindicate the infringed right and an appropriate relief may be achieved in the general claims of damages. In this case the court found that it would be inappropriate to award punitive constitutional damages in addition to the compensatory damages already awarded to the applicant. The court further held that damages against government would not have the intended impact of deterrence unless the money awarded was substantial in nature. The result of this would deplete already limited state resources and place the burden on tax payers. It would further be inappropriate where damages have already been awarded.

In this case the court considered section 38 of the constitution which states that a court can award appropriate relief ‘where a right in the Bill of Rights is violated, and what constitutes appropriate relief’ The court found that the appellant succeeded in proving that he was indeed assaulted by members of the police therefore he would be awarded substantial compensatory damages for pain and suffering, insult, shock, past and future medical expenses and loss of enjoyment of the amenities of life. Therefore his constitutional rights would be effectively vindicated without the awarding of constitutional damages. The court held that determining appropriate relief must be done according to the facts of the individual case. The relief must be one that effectively protects, enforces and vindicates the constitutional right which has been contravened. The court further held that courts will be required in certain instances to be innovative in ensuring that relief is achieved.

The court further held that punitive constitutional damages awarded against the government would not have the intended impact of deterrence unless the money awarded was substantial in nature. The result of this would deplete already limited state resources and place the burden on tax payers. It would further be inappropriate where damages have already been awarded, therefore the punitive damages claim are dismissed.

In the separate concurring judgement, Justice Didcott held that section 38 does not authorise punitive damages in this case. Future considerations of punitive damages similar to the one claimed in this case must be introduced by law and not through judicial innovation as suggested in the majority judgment.

Justice Kriegler held that the vindication as mentioned requires special consideration. That the purpose of the section is to ensure that certain violations are addressed and if they are not, it will result in loss of faith in the constitution. The courts must in exercising discretion to choose between appropriate forms of relief must carefully analyse the nature of a constitutional infringement and the probable impact of a particular remedy. The facts surrounding a violation of rights will determine what form of relief is appropriate.

cases.title: Carmichele v Minister of Safety and Security
cases.justicesConcurring: Ackermann J, and Goldstone J [Chaskalson P, Kriegler J, Madala J, Mokgoro J, Ngcobo J, Sachs J, Yacoob J, Madlanga AJ and Somyalo AJ]
cases.summary:
The applicant was sexually assaulted by a man who was awaiting trial for the attempted rape of another woman. Despite the seriousness of the alleged crime and the fact that the man had a prior rape conviction, the police and prosecutor had recommended that the man be released pending trial. The applicant sued the Minister for damages, arguing that the police and prosecutors had negligently failed to comply with a legal duty they owed to her to take steps to prevent the man from causing her harm. The High Court dismissed the applicant's claim and the Supreme Court of Appeal affirmed, holding that the police and prosecution did not owe her a duty of protection. The applicant sought relief from the Constitutional Court to determine whether the police and prosecutors owed a duty of care to a victim of sexual violence, and, if so, whether that standard of care was breached.

At issue in this case was whether the police or prosecutors owed a duty of care to a victim of sexual violence, and, if so, whether that standard of care was breached. The applicant argued that due consideration should have given prior to the release of the accused particularly given the prevalence of gender-based violence in South Africa, there should have been a special concern by the state as a constitutional obligation not to do anything that could further the possibility of violence. The respondent argued that the law stated that a mistake by a judicial officer that leads to bad consequences as in the applicants case can’t be the basis for seeking damages in court. Further that the state did not have a ‘duty of care’ to someone in applicants position.

The Court found that the police have positive obligations to protect the fundamental rights and freedoms contained in the Bill of Rights. The police, therefore, had to reasonably protect women from sexual violence, and their failure to do so would result in liability.

The Court also emphasised South Africa’s duty under international law to prohibit all gender-based discrimination. The Court noted that the police are one of the primary agencies of the state responsible for the protection of the public in general, and women in particular, against the violation of their fundamental rights by perpetrators of violent crime. The Court found that the police, therefore, had a duty to protect applicant and granted damages sought.

The Court held that section 173 of the Constitution gives all courts the power to develop the common law in the interests of justice. Section 39(2) of the Constitution provides that when developing the common law, every court must promote the spirit, purport, and objects of the Bill of Rights. The Court held that where the law does deviate from this standard, the courts have an obligation to act. In deciding whether a duty of care existed in this case, the court looked to the relevant statutory provisions that imposed positive obligations on members of the police force to preserve freedom and security.

The Court noted that in addressing such obligations in relation to dignity and the freedom and security of the person, “few things can be more important to women than freedom from the threat of sexual violence.” The Court held that the police is one of the primary agencies of the state responsible for the protection of the public in general, and women in particular, against the violation of their fundamental rights by perpetrators of violent crime. The court found that the police, therefore, had a duty toward the applicant and had breached that duty. The court therefore awarded the applicant damages.

cases.title: S v Makwanyane and Another
cases.justicesConcurring: Chaskalson P, Ackermann J, Didcott J, Kentridge AJ, Langa J, Madala J, Mahomed J, Mokgoro J, O’Regan J, Sachs J

topics.title: Section 1: Republic of South Africa
topics.content:
Section one of the Constitution provides the founding values on which the Republic of South Africa is founded on. It essentially re-affirms a new state order and confirms a clear break-away from the apartheid State system characterised by unrestrained State power. It firstly confirms that the Republic of South Africa is “one, sovereign, democratic state”. This confirmation in itself is critical as South Africa was prior to 1994 divided into various homelands (Bantustans) of which Black South Africans were made citizens of. Section one furthermore confirms that the Republic of South Africa is founded on various founding values such as human dignity, non-racialism, supremacy of the Constitution and a multi-party system of democratic governance.

It is critical to note that an amendment to section one of the Constitution requires a high threshold. At least 75 per cent of the members of the National Assembly have to support the proposed amendment with a supporting vote of at least six provinces in the National Council of Provinces. It is therefore always important to question whether any proposed amendment to the Constitution indirectly affects the founding values in section one of the Constitution.
topics.snippet: Section one of the Constitution provides the founding values on which the Republic of South Africa is founded on.

topics.title: Section 2: Supremacy of the Constitution
topics.content:
Section 2 of the Constitution provides that the Constitution is the “supreme law of the Republic; law or conduct inconsistent with it is invalid, and the obligations imposed by it must be fulfilled”. This section forms part of the founding provisions of South Africa’s new constitutional order and reaffirms a clear break away from the doctrine of Parliament sovereignty.

Under the doctrine of parliament sovereignty, Parliament had the power to make any law it wished and a Court could only declare the law invalid if there were procedural defects in the passing thereof. Under the apartheid state, acting under the doctrine of Parliament sovereignty, South Africa’s Parliament was not represented by all races. Legislation passed by Parliament therefore only advanced the interests of the white minority and trampled on the human rights of all other races. However, due to the doctrine of Parliament sovereignty the Courts were unable to declare an Act of Parliament invalid on the basis that it violated human rights and could only declare an Act invalid if there were procedural defects.

Under the doctrine of constitutional supremacy, all laws have to comply with the Constitution and the entrenched Bill of Rights in the Constitution. The Courts are now in the position to declare legislation that unduly infringes on a right in the Bill of Rights invalid.
topics.snippet: Section 2 of the Constitution provides that the Constitution is the “supreme law of the Republic; law or conduct inconsistent with it is invalid, and the obligations imposed by it must be fulfilled”.

topics.title: Section 3: Citizenship
topics.content:
Section 3 of the Constitution stipulates that there is a common South African citizenship and that all citizens of South Africa are not only equally entitled to the rights, privileges and benefits of citizenship but are also equally subject to the duties and responsibilities of citizenship. The State is obliged to enact national legislation to define citizenship and the South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 provides for the acquisition, loss and resumption of South African citizenship.

The recognition of the right to citizenship as a founding provision in the Constitution must be understood in its historical context. Under the apartheid State, black South Africans were not recognised as citizens of South Africa and were made citizens of defined territories (known as Homelands) under the Bantu Homelands Citizenship Act 26 of 1970. Under South Africa’s new constitutional dispensation, the right to citizenship in the Constitution is deeply couched on the recognition of equality. The right to citizenship allows a person to access various rights such as the right to political representation and freedom of movement. However it is important to understand that the Constitutional Court has confirmed at various occasions that arbitrary distinctions between citizens and non-citizens are not consistent with the Constitution and the rights in the Bill of Rights are afforded to everyone, with certain exceptions.
topics.snippet: Section 3 of the Constitution stipulates that there is a common South African citizenship and that all citizens of South Africa are not only equally entitled to the rights, privileges and benefits of citizenship but are also equally subject to the duties and responsibilities of citizenship.

topics.title: Section 4: National Anthem
topics.content:
Section 4 of the Constitution provides that the national anthem of the Republic of South Africa is determined by proclamation. Up until 1994, South Africa’s official national anthem was Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, which was based on a 1918 poem by CJ Langenhoven. In 1994, former President Nelson Mandela announced that in addition to Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, Nkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika would also be a national anthem. Nkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika was originally a church hymn but was later associated with the African National Congress and was regularly sung in defiance of the apartheid regime. In 1997, Former President Nelson Mandela proclaimed the new national anthem for the Republic of South Africa, which is a combined version of “Nkosi Sikelel iAfrika” and “Die Stem van Suid-Afrika” (“The Call of South Africa”).

The national anthem reflects a commitment to heal the divisions of the past as per the Preamble of the Constitution and reflects unity in diversity.
topics.snippet: Section 4 of the Constitution provides that the national anthem of the Republic of South Africa is determined by proclamation.

topics.title: Section 5: National Flag
topics.content: Section 5 of the Constitution provides that the national flag of the Republic is black, gold, green, white, red and blue, as described and sketched in Schedule 1 to the Constitution. The national flag was designed by a former South African State Herald, Mr Fred Brownwell. The national flag was used for the first time on 27 April 1994 and the central design of the flag, the ‘V’ form flowing into a single horizontal band according to official the Government publications may be interpreted “as the convergence of diverse elements within South African society, taking the road ahead in unity”.
topics.snippet: Section 5 of the Constitution provides that the national flag of the Republic is black, gold, green, white, red and blue, as described and sketched in Schedule 1 to the Constitution.

topics.title: Section 6: Languages
topics.content:
Section 6 of the Constitution recognises that the official languages of the Republic are Sepedi, Sesotho, Setswana, siSwati, Tshivenda, Xitsonga, Afrikaans, English, isiNdebele, isiXhosa and isiZulu. This section further recognises the “historically diminished use and status of the indigenous languages” and obliges the State to take “practical and positive measures to elevate the status and advance the use of these languages”. National and provincial governments are furthermore obliged to regulate and monitor the use of official languages by legislative and other measures and all official languages must be treated equitably.

The Use of Official Languages Act 12 of 2012 has been specifically enacted to give effect to the constitutional obligations in terms of section 6 of the Constitution.

Section 6 of the Constitution also obliges the creation of a Pan South African Language Board that has to promote and create conditions for the development and use of all official languages, the Khoi, Nama and San languages and sign language in specific. The recognition of the South African Sign Language (“SASL”) as the 12th official language has been a longstanding issue and in 2017, Parliament’s Joint Constitutional Review Committee recommended that SASL be recognised as the 12th official language which would require a constitutional amendment.
topics.snippet: Section 6 of the Constitution recognises that the official languages of the Republic are Sepedi, Sesotho, Setswana, siSwati, Tshivenda, Xitsonga, Afrikaans, English, isiNdebele, isiXhosa and isiZulu.

topics.title: Section 7: Rights
topics.content:
Section 7 of the Constitution provides that the Bill of Rights is a “cornerstone of democracy in South Africa”. Section 7 furthermore holds that the rights in the Bill of Rights “enshrines the rights of all people in our country and affirms the democratic values of human dignity, equality and freedom”.

The first recognition of the protection of human rights, the most fundamental rights inherent to every person, was found in the Interim Constitution and is a key development of the constitutional transformation South Africa followed after the dismantlement of apartheid laws. Chapter 2 of the Final Constitution (the Bill of Rights) reinforces the protection and fulfilment of human rights.

The rights in the Bill of Rights may be limited in terms of the Constitutional test provided for in section 36 of the Constitution and some rights have internal qualifiers as well, such as the right to housing for instance. It is however important that any limitation of a right in the Bill of Rights be tested against the Constitution in order to be justified as a reasonable limitation.
topics.snippet: Section 7 of the Constitution provides that the Bill of Rights is a “cornerstone of democracy in South Africa”.

topics.title: Section 8: Application
topics.content:
Section 8 of the Constitution stipulates that the Bill of Rights, Chapter 2 of the Constitution, applies to all law and binds the legislature, the executive, the judiciary and all organs of state. Importantly the Bill of Rights not only applies to the State but also to natural or juristic persons, to the extent applicable considering the nature of the rights and the nature of the duty imposed. For instance, the State has to ensure that every citizen has the right to vote in the elections and this is a constitutional duty only the State can fulfil. The State may not deprive a citizen of this right. This form of application of the Bill of Rights is known as the vertical application of rights and this relationship relates more to protecting an individual against State power.

However, a constitutional right such as privacy can for instance be enforced between individuals and between individuals there is the duty to uphold this right equally. This form of application of the Bill of Rights is known as the horizontal application of the Bill of Rights.
topics.snippet: Section 8 of the Constitution stipulates that the Bill of Rights, Chapter 2 of the Constitution, applies to all law and binds the legislature, the executive, the judiciary and all organs of state.

topics.title: Section 9: Equality
topics.content:
Section 9 of the Constitution protects the right to equality and it provides that everyone is entitled to equal protection and benefit of the law. Furthermore section 9 prohibits unfair discrimination based on certain listed characteristics such as race, sexual orientation and belief and the State is obliged to design measures to protect and advance certain categories of persons that have been previously disadvantaged.

It is important to note that the constitutional guarantee to the right to equality includes both formal and substantive equality. Essentially formal equality requires that individuals in the same circumstances must be treated alike. However identical treatment alone is not enough to achieve the goal of an equal society the Constitution envisions. It fails to take into account that social, economic and historical injustices impact individuals differently and measures attempting to advance equality should address these realities.
topics.snippet: Section 9 of the Constitution protects the right to equality and it provides that everyone is entitled to equal protection and benefit of the law.

topics.title: Section 10: Human Dignity
topics.content:
Section 10 of the Constitution recognises that everyone has the right to inherent dignity and the right to have their dignity respected and promoted. The concept of dignity is a difficult concept to describe but essentially it involves the inherent recognition of the intrinsic worth of every person.

It is important to note that the right to dignity provides the foundation of many other rights in the Bill of Rights and besides being an enforceable right in the Bill of Rights, it is also a foundational value of South Africa’s new constitutional order in terms of section 1 of the Constitution. The right to human dignity is also interlinked with democracy and in essence the right to human dignity recognises that people have the right and freedom to make their own choices.
topics.snippet: Section 10 of the Constitution recognises that everyone has the right to inherent dignity and the right to have their dignity respected and promoted.

topics.title: Section 11: Life
topics.content:
Section 11 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to life and is an unqualified right. It is important to understand that although the right to life is unqualified it does not mean it cannot be justifiably limited in terms of section 36 of the Constitution, the limitation of rights provision in the Constitution. For instance, law permitting the right to kill in self-defence is a justifiable limitation to the right to life or the police using force in very limited circumstances.

The constitutionality of the death penalty was one of the Constitutional Court’s first ground-breaking judgments and although the majority judgment did not focus on the right to life, the other concurring judgments emphasised that the right to life is interlinked with the right to dignity. Importantly the right to life was described as the right to experience humanity and reflects each individual’s worth and value in a society.
topics.snippet: Section 11 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to life and is an unqualified right.

topics.title: Section 12: Freedom and Security of the Person
topics.content:
Section 12 of the Constitution not only affords everyone the right to freedom and security of the person but it also affords everyone the right to bodily and psychological integrity. It is important to understand that the right to freedom and security of the person which involves various aspects such as the right not to deprived of freedom arbitrarily and the right not to be tortured, guarantees both substantive and procedural protection.

The substantive aspect of the right to freedom and security of the person essentially requires a rational reason for the deprivation of a person’s freedom whereas the procedural aspect of the right relates to procedural fairness and due process and will depend on the circumstances of each case.

The right to bodily and psychological integrity, extends to the right to make reproductive choices, to be in security and control of one’s own body and not to be subjected to medical or scientific experiments without giving informed consent. The Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act 92 of 1996 was specifically enacted to give expression to the right to make reproductive choices.
topics.snippet: Section 12 of the Constitution not only affords everyone the right to freedom and security of the person but it also affords everyone the right to bodily and psychological integrity.

topics.title: Section 13: Slavery, Servitude and Forced Labour
topics.content: Section 13 of the Constitution provides that no one may be subjected to slavery, servitude or forced labour. In the modern-day sense “slavery” could be understood as submitting a person to another person’s control, making that person an “owner” of the person. South Africa is a signatory to various international law conventions obliging States to eradicate slavery and servitude such as the 1956 Supplementary Convention on the Abolition of Slavery, the Slave Trade and Institutions and Practices Similar to Slavery. In 2013, the Prevention and Combatting of Trafficking in Persons Act 7 of 2013 was specifically enacted to give effect to South Africa’s international and constitutional obligations in this regard and the Act provides measures to specifically protect and assist victims of trafficking.
topics.snippet: Section 13 of the Constitution provides that no one may be subjected to slavery, servitude or forced labour.

topics.title: Section 14: Privacy
topics.content: Section 14 of the Constitution not only guarantees everyone a general right to privacy but also provides protection against specific instances of privacy violations such as the right not to have one’s home searched, property seized and the right to the privacy of one’s communications. The constitutional protection afforded to the right to privacy has been interpreted by the Constitutional Court to extend to aspects of a person’s life to which a “legitimate expectation of privacy” exist. On considering whether a violation of the right to privacy occurred the Courts will not only consider the subjective expectation of privacy but also the objective component of the expectation of privacy, considering whether society would recognise the expectation as reasonable. The Protection of Personal Information Act 4 of 2013 was specifically enacted to give effect to the right to informational privacy and the Act provides strict measures for the processing of personal information by public and private bodies. The Information Regulator established in terms of the Act is an independent body empowered to monitor compliance of the Act.
topics.snippet: Section 14 of the Constitution not only guarantees everyone a general right to privacy but also provides protection against specific instances of privacy violations such as the right not to have one’s home searched, property seized and the right to the privacy of one’s communications.

topics.title: Section 15: Freedom of Religion, Belief and Opinion
topics.content: Section 15(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion. The right to religious freedom also extends the right not to hold such beliefs. The drafters of the Constitution were conscious of providing equal treatment to all religions and to ensure constitutional protection to the right to freedom of thought and belief, which includes atheism and free thought. Section 15(2) of the Constitution stipulates that religious observances may be held at State-aided institutions under certain conditions such as the need to ensure that attendance thereof is in terms of rules by a public authority, are conducted on an equitable basis and is free and voluntary. Section 15(3) of the Constitution empowers the State to enact legislation to recognise customary and religious marriages and the Recognition of Customary Marriages Act 120 of 1998 affords legal recognition to customary marriages prescribing to certain requirements and provides equal status to spouses in customary marriages.
topics.snippet: Section 15(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion.

topics.title: Section 16: Freedom of Expression
topics.content:
Section 16(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of expression which not only encompasses freedom of the press, freedom to receive or impart information, freedom of artistic creativity but also academic and scientific freedom.

Section 16(2) of the Constitution however specifically delineates what forms of expression are not constitutionally protected and the right to freedom of expression does not extend to these categories of expression. These limited categories include propaganda to war; the incitement to imminent violence or advocacy of hatred that is based on race, ethnicity, gender or religion and that constitutes incitement to harm. The last category is colloquially known as the hate speech prohibition.

A form of expression falls into one of the limited categories in terms of section 16(2) of the Constitution, it is not constitutionally protected and the question whether it limits the right to freedom of expression does not arise. However, if the form of expression does not fall into one of these limited categories it is in fact constitutionally protected expression and any legislative attempts to regulate and/or limit such expression must satisfy the limitation of rights test in terms of section 36 of the Constitution.
topics.snippet: Section 16(1) of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of expression which not only encompasses freedom of the press, freedom to receive or impart information, freedom of artistic creativity but also academic and scientific freedom.

topics.title: Section 17: Assembly, Demonstration, PIcket and Petition
topics.content:
Section 17 of the Constitution protects the right to assemble, to demonstrate, to picket and to present petitions on the condition that they are held “peacefully and unarmed”. Protests and assemblies provided a powerful mechanism in the struggle against apartheid and the constitutional protection of the right must be viewed in this historical context. The right is also a critical form of engagement in a democratic society, providing a political tool for marginal groups in specific.

The Regulations of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993 specifically gives effect to section 17 of the Constitution and provides detail on the lawful conduct of gatherings. The Act however faced a constitutional challenge and in 2018 the Constitutional Court found section 12(1)(a) of the Act, which made failure to notify the relevant authority of a gathering a criminal offence, unconstitutional and invalid.
topics.snippet: Section 17 of the Constitution protects the right to assemble, to demonstrate, to picket and to present petitions on the condition that they are held “peacefully and unarmed”.

topics.title: Section 18: Freedom of Association
topics.content:
Section 18 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of association. The right has been described as a correlative right and it reinforces other rights in the Bill of Rights. For instance, the right reinforces individuals right to form a political party and reinforces workers’ right to form and join a trade union. The right to its core protects the choice of individuals and limits State interference.

It is however important to emphasise that the right to freedom of association also extends to the right not to be forced to associate. This negative dimension of the right to freedom of choice played a critical role in the Constitutional Court’s finding that the Electoral Act 73 of 1998 was unconstitutional to the extend that it prohibited an independent candidate to contest national and provincial elections.
topics.snippet: Section 18 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of association.

topics.title: Section 19: Political Rights
topics.content:
Section 19 of the Constitution stipulates broad political rights such as the right to form a political party, the right to campaign for a political party and cause and it guarantees the right of every citizen to participate in free, fair and regular elections and to stand for public office if so elected. The broad spectrum of political rights guaranteed in the Constitution must be viewed in its historical context where the majority of South African citizens were denied the right to participate in representative politics. Section 19 of the Constitution therefore give effect to representative democracy.

The Electoral Act 73 of 1998 regulates elections of the National Assembly, the Provincial Legislature and Municipal councils. In 2020 the Constitutional Court found that the Electoral Act is unconstitutional to the extent that independent candidates were not able to be elected for the National Assembly and Provincial Legislature and Parliament has been mandated to remedy this defect.
topics.snippet: Section 19 of the Constitution stipulates broad political rights such as the right to form a political party, the right to campaign for a political party and cause and it guarantees the right of every citizen to participate in free, fair and regular elections and to stand for public office if so elected.

topics.title: Section 20: Citizenship
topics.content:
Section 20 of the Constitution stipulates that no citizen may be deprived of citizenship. This right can be described as a right against statelessness and it is aligned with South Africa’s international law commitments not to deprive a citizen arbitrarily of his or her citizenship and to provide protection against statelessness which has serious consequences. The Constitutional Court has held that that citizenship is directly interlinked with the right to dignity and is much more than a legal status as it is central to a person’s identity.

The South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 provides the manner for acquisition for South African citizenship and chapter 3 of the Act deals specifically with the loss of citizenship.
topics.snippet: Section 20 of the Constitution stipulates that no citizen may be deprived of citizenship.

topics.title: Section 21: Freedom of Movement and Residence
topics.content:
Section 21 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of movement and residence and stipulates that not only has every citizen the right to enter, remain and reside anywhere in the Republic but everyone also has the right to move freely and to leave the Republic. Furthermore, in terms of section 21 of the Constitution, every citizen also has the right to a passport.

The right has to be seen against the fact that apartheid laws imposed great restrictions on the free movement of people in the country and the constitutional recognition of the right of people to move freely and for citizens to acquire a passport is a clear break-away from the authoritarian rule of the apartheid government. It is important to note that the right to freely move and leave the Republic is afforded to everyone while the right to enter, remain, reside and the right to a passport is only afforded to citizens.
topics.snippet: Section 21 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to freedom of movement and residence and stipulates that not only has every citizen the right to enter, remain and reside anywhere in the Republic but everyone also has the right to move freely and to leave the Republic.

topics.title: Section 24: Environment
topics.content: Section 24 of the Constitution confirms that everyone has a right to an environment that is not “harmful to their health or well-being” and places a positive obligation on the State to protect the environment for the benefit of future and present generations. The State is obliged to publish legislation and take other administrative steps to ensure it fulfils this duty and if the State fails an individual can evoke section 24 of the Constitution. It is imperative to note that this constitutional obligation not only applies to the State but action by companies and individuals can also be measured against this constitutional obligation. An important addition in the Final Constitution was ensuring the State secures ecological sustainable developments and the use of natural resources.
topics.snippet: Section 24 of the Constitution confirms that everyone has a right to an environment that is not “harmful to their health or well-being” and places a positive obligation on the State to protect the environment for the benefit of future and present generations.

topics.title: Section 25: Property Rights
topics.content:
Section 25 of the Constitution, the property provision in the Bill of Rights has both protecting and reformative provisions and it is important to understand this balance. On the on hand the right protects existing property rights and on the other hand the right aims to correct historical injustices. Section 25(1) to (3) of the Constitution essentially provides protection against arbitrary deprivation of property and stipulates the requirements for expropriation. The protection of property against unconstitutional interreference is also directly reflected in international conventions, which South Africa has to adhere to such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Section 25(4) to (9) of the Constitution can be described as the “reformative provisions” and obliges the State to take action to promote land and other reforms to ensure equitable access to South Africa’s natural resources.

In December 2019, the Ad Hoc Committee on the Amendment of Section 25 of the Constitution published the Constitution Eighteenth Amendment Bill, which aimed to amend section 25 of the Constitution to provide that where land and any other improvements are expropriated for the purpose of land reform, the amount of compensation may be nil. It is important to note that as the Bill relates to an amendment of a right in the Bill of Rights such an amendment can only pass with a supporting vote of at least two thirds of the members in the National Assembly and a supporting vote of at least six provinces in the National Council of Provinces.
topics.snippet: Section 25 of the Constitution, the property provision in the Bill of Rights has both protecting and reformative provisions and it is important to understand this balance.

topics.title: Section 28: Children
topics.content:
Section 28 of the Constitution provides a range of rights to children, extending from the right to legal identity, such as the constitutional protection of a child’s right to a name and nationality to the right to parental care and the right to be protected from exploitative labour practices.
The constitutional rights extended to children specifically in terms of section 28 of the Constitution is in addition to any other constitutional rights in terms of the Bill of Rights where applicable. The purpose of section 28 of the Constitution is to specifically protect children in vulnerable situations. The State has a constitutional obligation to enact legislation providing more detail on the rights in terms of section 28 of the Constitution and the Children’s Act 38 of 2005 has been specifically enacted to give effect to these rights.
The “best interests of a Child” standard has been cemented in the Constitution and section 28(2) of the Constitution emphasises that- “A child’s best interests are of paramount importance in every matter concerning the child”. This standard provides that in a legal dispute concerning children for instance, the Court must focus on what would be best for the child in the circumstances before focusing on the rights and preferences of the parents.  The “best interests” standard also obliges the State to take action to ensure the necessary legal and administrative structures are in place to protect children.

topics.title: Section 29: Education
topics.content:
Section 29 of the Constitution provides for education rights and it stipulates that everyone has the right to basic education and to “further education, which the state, through reasonable measures, must make progressively available and accessible.” Unlike other socio-economic rights in the Bill of Rights, the right to basic education is an absolute right and lack of resources cannot justify its constraint. With the right to further education, the State is not obliged to provide access to everyone immediately. The State is only obliged to take reasonable measures over time to provide access to such institutions.

As the right to basic education extends to “everyone” it is not only restricted to citizens and applies to non-citizens as well. Furthermore, the content of the right to basic education is not only restricted to access to available places at schools but includes teaching materials and ensuring the facilities are appropriate for learning.

Section 29(2) also provides that where it is reasonably practicable the State is obliged to provide education in an official language of choice. This right is again restricted by internal qualifiers and has been the subject of many legal disputes. Lastly section 29(3) of the Constitution provides protection for the right to establish independent schools subject to the schools not discriminating on the basis of race, registering with the State and maintaining appropriate standards. Importantly the State is not obliged to make available resources to such schools as they operate at their own expense and the State only has a negative duty not to interfere with such schools.

topics.title: Section 30: Language and Culture
topics.content:
Section 30 of the Constitution affords protection to the right to use one’s own language and to participate in the cultural life of one’s choice. It is however on the condition that these rights may not be exercised in a manner that is inconsistent with other fundamental human rights guaranteed in the Bill of Rights. For instance, the right to exercise a cultural practice must be consistent with an individual’s right to dignity and freedom and security of the person. If the right is practised in a manner that endangers a person’s life then it is inconsistent with the constitutional protection afforded in terms of section 30 of the Constitution and the State will have to intervene to protect the individual.

Section 30 of the Constitution is one of various provisions in the Constitution affording protection to ethnic, religious and linguistic groups in South Africa and also reflects international law commitments to provide protection to such groups.

topics.title: Section 31: Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities
topics.content:
Section 31 of the Constitution affords protection to cultural, religious or linguistic communities. Persons belonging to such groups may not be denied the right to enjoy their culture, practise their religion and use their language. The State may also not interfere with the rights of persons belonging to such groups to form and maintain cultural, religious and linguistic associations. It is important to note that these rights may not be exercised in a manner inconsistent with any provisions of the Bill of Rights. For instance, if a religious practice by a community harms an individual’s life then section 31 of the Constitution cannot be relied on as the individual’s right to freedom and security of the person is endangered.

It is also important to note that section 31 of the Constitution protects both the religious, cultural and linguistic interests of an individual and that of a community but for an individual to claim the rights in terms this section, the individual needs to prove that there is a link between themselves and the specific group. Section 31 of the Constitution is also specifically based on article 27 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and therefore the constitutional protection afforded to cultural, religious and linguistic communities is aligned with international law.

topics.title: Section 32: Access to Information
topics.content:
Section 32 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to access to “any information held by the State” as well as “any information held by another person and that is required for the exercise or protection of any rights.”. The State is obliged to enact national legislation to give effect to these constitutional rights and the Promotion of Access to Information Act 2 of 2000 specifically gives effect to these rights.

The guarantee of this constitutional right is a commitment to break away from the authoritarian state enforced by the apartheid government. Access to information is critical to ensure accountability, transparency and is a powerful defence against corruption.

topics.title: Section 33: Just Administrative Action
topics.content:
Section 33 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to “administrative action that is lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair” and provides individuals with the right to claim relief where their rights have been adversely affected by administrative action. Administrative action involves the exercise of public power by all organs of State. The State is obliged to enact national legislation to give effect to

section 33 of the Constitution and the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 200 specifically gives effect to these rights. Certain public action however does not fall under “administrative action” and is not reviewable in terms of the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act. This for instance includes judicial action by the judiciary, the President when exercising his powers in terms of the Constitution, the legislature when exercising their functions and political decisions by the cabinet.

The protection of the constitutional right to just administrative action reflects a deep commitment to restrain discretionary power afforded to the executive. The apartheid State was characterised by unlimited power afforded to the State in terms of national legislation. Under South Africa’s new constitutional order such power will now have to comply with the Constitution and has to be lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair.

topics.title: Section 34: Access to Courts
topics.content:
Section 34 of the Constitution guarantees everyone the right to have a dispute that can be resolved by the application of law decided in a fair public hearing before a court or where appropriate by another independent and impartial tribunal or forum.

This constitutional right provides a strong defence against the abuse of public power and upholds one of the founding values of the Constitution, namely the Rule of Law which essentially embraces equal protection of the law and ensures the powers of the judiciary are not usurped by the Legislature or the Executive.

It is important to emphasise that this constitutional right cannot be interpreted to mean that an individual can approach any court or independent tribunal to resolve a specific dispute as the rules of jurisdiction still apply. However, an individual has the right to approach a competent court or tribunal where appropriate to resolve the dispute and cannot be forced to waive this right.

topics.title: Section 35: Arrested, Detained and Accused Persons
topics.content:
The criminal justice system has been extensively revolutionised under South Africa’s new constitutional order and reflects stringent checks and balances to ensure police power is not abused. Section 35 of the Constitution specifically provides for the rights of arrested, detained and accused persons and the range of constitutional rights in this section will only be of application once a person falls into one of these categories.

Section 35(1)(a) of the Constitution for instance specifically provides that a person arrested for allegedly committing an offence has the right to remain silent including various other rights such as the right not to be compelled to make any confessions or admissions. A detained person in terms of section 35(2) of the Constitution, including every sentenced person has for instance the right to be informed promptly of the reason for being detained and an accused person in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution has the right to a fair trial which includes various rights such as the right to be informed of the charge with sufficient detail to answer.

Section 35(5) of the Constitution specifically provides a remedy for breach of constitutional rights and stipulates that evidence obtained in a manner that violates any right in the Bill of Rights must be excluded if the “admission of that evidence would render the trial unfair or otherwise be detrimental to the administration of justice”.
